Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six (6) months or by both such fine and imprisonment. In addition to such fine or imprisonment, violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of the occupation tax certificate issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 98-6, Pt. 1, 8-4-98) 
Sec. 12-328. - Unlawful operation declared nuisance. 
Any adult entertainment establishment operated, conducted or maintained contrary to the provisions of this chapter shall be and the same is declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. The city may, in addition to, or in lieu of prosecuting a criminal action hereunder, commence an action or actions, proceeding or proceedings for abatement, removal or enjoinment thereof, in the manner provided by law. It shall take such other steps and shall apply to such courts as may have jurisdiction to grant such relief as will abate or remove such adult entertainment establishment and restrain and enjoin any person from operating, conducting or maintaining an adult entertainment establishment contrary to the provisions of this chapter. In addition, violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be per se grounds for suspension or revocation of the occupation tax certificate granted hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 98-6, Pt. 1, 8-4-98) 
Sec. 12-329. - Revocation and appeal. 
(a)  The chief of police shall be authorized to suspend or revoke an occupation tax certificate previously granted herein. In the event the chief of police seeks to suspend or to revoke an occupation tax certificate, the chief of police shall give written notification to the applicant of such action and such notice shall contain a specification of the violation or violations and shall be served upon the licensee at least five (5) days prior to the notice of hearing. The applicant shall be given written notice of the time and place of the hearing. 
(b)  The chief of police shall be authorized to suspend or revoke an occupation tax certificate in the event of any one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  An applicant gave false or misleading information in the original application process; 
(2)  An applicant has knowingly allowed possession, use, or sale of controlled substances on the premises and/or knowingly allowed possession, use, or sale of controlled substances to a minor on the premises; 
(3)  An applicant has knowingly allowed the violation of an ordinance of the city or a violation of any criminal law of the state to occur on the premises; 
(4)  An applicant has violated any provision of this adult entertainment chapter; 
(5)  An applicant has been convicted of any drug-related, alcohol-related or sex-related crime by the state or the city regarding an offense which was committed on the premises or which would otherwise violate the provisions of this chapter; and 
(6)  An applicant fails to pay any fee, occupation tax fine or other amount of money due to the city under this chapter or any other taxing ordinance of the city. 
(c)  In the event the chief of police shall suspend or revoke any occupation tax certificate hereunder, the suspension or revocation shall be for a period of not less than one (1) day nor more than three hundred sixty-five (365) days, within the discretion of the chief of police. Provided, however, that the applicant shall be authorized to continue its business operations until the date of the hearing scheduled in accordance with subsection (d) of this section. No applicant may apply for an occupation tax certificate during any period of suspension or revocation. In any hearing conducted by the chief of police, the chief shall consider, among other things, the severity of the allegations, the evidence submitted and the testimony presented, in making any decision on suspension, revocation and the duration of either. 
(d)  In the event of a suspension or revocation by the chief of police, the applicant may appeal the decision of the chief of police to the mayor and city council for the city by filing a written notice of appeal within ten (10) days from the date of the decision of the chief of police. Thereafter, a hearing shall be scheduled before the mayor and council for the city within forty-five (45) days after the date of the notice of appeal by the applicant. After hearing by the mayor and city council, the city council may take such action as it deems appropriate, including the upholding of the action of the chief of police or the imposition of such action as the mayor and city council may deem appropriate under the facts. The decision of the mayor and city council shall be final. Appeals from the decision of the mayor and city council shall be to the Superior Court of DeKalb County filed within thirty (30) days of the final action of the mayor and city council. In the event the applicant does not file an appeal from any decision of the chief of police, as provided herein, the decision of the chief of police shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 98-6, Pt. 1, 8-4-98) 
Sec. 12-330. - Occupation tax certificate and annual renewal fees. 
The adult entertainment establishment occupation tax and any renewal fee for such occupation tax certificate shall be based on the gross receipts schedule pursuant to the ordinance providing for the issuance of such occupation tax certificate. 
(Ord. No. 98-6, Pt. 1, 8-4-98) 
Sec. 12-331. - Unlawful to serve, sell, distribute or suffer the consumption or possession of any intoxicating liquor, beer, wine, distilled spirits or controlled substance upon premises of licensee. 
(a)  No person, association, partnership or corporation licensed under this chapter of the City Code after the effective date of this article shall serve, sell, distribute or suffer the consumption or possession of any intoxicating liquor, beer or wine, distilled spirits or controlled substance upon the premises of any licensee. Any licensee whose license was granted prior to the adoption of this amendment shall not be subject to this amendment until December 31, 1998, at which time all licensees within the city shall be subject to this provision, including those licensees licensed before the effective date hereof. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the premises of nor prohibit the live performance of legitimate plays, operas or ballets at any mainstream theater, concert, hall, museum or educational institution which derives less than twenty (20) percent of its gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 98-6, Pt. 1, 8-4-98) 
Sec. 12-332. - Change of location. 
There is established an administrative fee of ten dollars ($10.00) to apply for a change of location for an adult entertainment establishment. 
(Ord. No. 98-6, Pt. 1, 8-4-98) 
Chapter 13 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Adoption of Uniform Rules of the Road. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, 40-6-1 through 40-6-395 of that chapter known as the Uniform Rules of the Road and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited herein. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1022) 
Sec. 13-2. - Reserved 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 06-06, pt. I, adopted March 7, 2006, amended the Code by repealing former § 13-2 in its entirety. Former § 13-2 pertained to regulation of traffic at the cemetery; and derived from an ordinance of November 4, 1987. 
Cross reference— Cemeteries, ch. 6. 
Sec. 13-3. - Regulation of flow of traffic over city streets. 
(a)  The city council delegates to the chief of police and the city manager the power to regulate the flow of traffic over and across the streets of the city. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  The city manager and the chief of police are delegated the authority to acquire and post such signs as may be necessary in order to effectuate the traffic regulations they deem necessary and proper. Upon placement of such signs the instructions contained thereon shall be deemed to carry the force of law, and any violation thereof shall be deemed to be a misdemeanor punishable in the city court. 
(d)  The city council my, but its vote, change and repeal any decision made pursuant to this section by the chief of police and the city manager. 
(Ord. of 3-5-91(2), §§ 1—4; Ord. No. 06-06, pt. I, 3-7-06) 
Editor's note— Inclusion of the provisions of §§ 1—5 of an ordinance adopted Mar. 5, 1991, as § 13-3 was at the discretion of the editor, the ordinance being nonamendatory of the code. 
Secs. 13-4—13-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 13-26. - Speed limits—Generally. 
(a)  Except where otherwise provided by law or ordinance, the speed limit in the city shall be twenty-five (25) miles per hour. 
(b)  Speed limits in excess of twenty-five (25) miles per hour shall be enforced on the following roadways: 

 
(Code 1976, § 7-1001; Ord. No. 2013-08, pt. I, 9-3-13) 
State Law reference— Speed restrictions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-180 et seq.; alteration of speed limits by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. 
Secs. 13-26.5, 13-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 06-06, pt. I, adopted March 7, 2006, amended the Code by repealing former §§ 13-26.5 and 13-27. Former § 13-26.5 pertained to specific speed zones; and derived from Ord. No. 98-3, adopted April 7, 1998. Former § 13-27 pertained to school zones and church zones; and derived from the Code of 1976, § 7-1002. 
Sec. 13-28. - Same—Signs. 
All vehicle drivers approaching any speed limit sign placed upon any street in the city shall reduce their speed to not in excess of the posted limit and retain such speed until the particular zone has been passed. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1003) 
Sec. 13-29. - No-turn signs. 
The driver of any vehicle shall not make a turn at any intersection where an official sign prohibiting same is exhibited. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1004) 
Sec. 13-30. - No through streets. 
No thoroughfare marked by a sign to show that it is not a through street shall be used by the driver of any vehicle unless the driver enters the thoroughfare for the purpose of stopping thereon. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1012) 
Sec. 13-31. - Moving of houses, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move any type of house, building or large machinery through the public streets of the city without first obtaining a special written permit from the mayor and city council. 
(b)  Before such permit shall be considered by the mayor and city council, the moving parties shall present before the mayor and city council the width, height and length of the object being moved, the time the object shall pass through the city, the proper manpower to engineer the moving over the streets, insurance to cover any type of damages, and sufficient police officers to handle the traffic situation. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1017) 
Cross reference— Buildings, ch. 5. 
Sec. 13-32. - Regulation of off-road vehicles. 
(a)  Definition. For the purpose of this section, the term "off-road vehicle" means any motorized vehicle designed for or capable of cross-country travel on or immediately over land, water, snow, ice, marsh, swampland, or other natural terrain and not primarily intended for use predominantly on public roads. Such shall include motorized four-wheel drive or low pressure tire vehicles, two-wheel dirt bikes, three-wheel motorized vehicles, or motorcycles and other means of transportation deriving power from any source other than muscle or wind, except that such terms shall exclude motor boats; any military, fire or law enforcement vehicle; farm machinery, tractors, and other self-propelled equipment for harvesting and transportation of forest products, for clearing land, for utilities services and maintenance, earth moving, construction or mining; and self-propelled lawnmowers, garden or lawn tractors, or golf carts, while such vehicles are being used exclusively for their designed purposes. 
(b)  Operation restrictions. Any person operating an off-road vehicle under any of the following conditions shall be deemed in violation of this section and subject to the penalties hereinafter provided: 
(1)  Without operative brakes, or without mufflers or other silencing equipment. 
(2)  On any private property without express written permission of the owner of the property or his agents. 
(3)  On the public streets of the city unless such are properly licensed by the state including any required emission or inspection certificates. 
(c)  Time restrictions. Subject to the licensing requirements of this section and the state, off-road vehicles may not be operated upon private property in the period from 8:00 p.m. in the evening until 8:00 a.m. in the morning. 
(Ord. of 4-7-87(2)) 
Sec. 13-33. - Streets designated for emergency vehicles only. 
No thoroughfare, lane or street, marked to show that it is for emergency vehicles only, shall be used by any driver of any vehicle unless that vehicle is owned by the city, county, state or federal governments and designated for use as a police vehicle, an emergency medical vehicle or a fire services vehicle. 
(Ord. of 8-4-87(1)) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 10; police, ch. 21; streets and sidewalks, ch. 25. 
Sec. 13-34. - Traffic control signs. 
Traffic control signs as designated on the following list shall be placed at the street locations as follows: 
West Mountain Street - No right turn on red at Main Street from 4:00 p.m. until 7:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 08-12, Pt. I, 10-7-08) 
Secs. 13-35—13-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 

Sec. 13-56. - Meaning of curb markings. 
The following meanings shall be given to curb markings designating requirements and prohibitions governing parking, standing and stopping: 
(1)  White shall indicate the lines wherein vehicles shall park in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Yellow paint shall indicate places where vehicles shall not park. 
(3)  Red paint shall indicate loading zones, taxicab zones, and other restrictive regulations indicated by posted signs. 
(4)  Blue paint shall indicate bus stops and places where parking is permitted for police vehicles and other city-owned vehicles as indicated by posted signs and in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 8-4-87(6), § 7-1026) 
Sec. 13-57. - Parking prohibited at all times on certain streets. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets described in the schedule kept on file in the city hall, hereby made a part hereof. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1013) 
Sec. 13-58. - Parking time limited on certain streets. 
When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle for longer than the times specified within the district or upon any of the streets described in the schedule kept on file in the city hall, hereby made a part hereof. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1014) 
Sec. 13-59. - Intersections where stop required. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, vehicles shall be stopped at the entrances to all intersections described in the schedule kept on file in the city hall, hereby made a part hereof. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1015) 
Sec. 13-60. - Parking at recreation facilities. 
(a)  Definition. Recreational facilities are those facilities within the city, whether owned or leased by the city, which are used as parks, tennis courts, swimming pools, playgrounds, athletic fields, gymnasiums, or any other related type activities. 
(b)  Parking prohibited. No person shall park in any parking lot or parking area provided incidental to any recreational facility unless such person is actively participating in the use of such recreational facility either as a participant in some activity conducted therein or as an observer thereof. 
(c)  Manner of parking. No person using a recreational facility shall park any vehicle in any area not designated as a permitted parking area nor shall any person using a recreational facility park any vehicle in such manner as to block the ingress or egress to such facility or parking areas incidental thereto. 
(d)  Exceptions. The restrictions set forth in this section shall not apply to any city-owned vehicle or any vehicle used by any person engaged in maintenance activities at any recreational facility. 
(Ord. of 8-4-87(6), § 7-1024) 
Cross reference— Parks and recreation, ch. 19. 
Secs. 13-61—13-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRUCK ROUTES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses and business regulations, ch. 12. 
Annotation— The provisions of the 1967 truck route ordinance (1) are not ultra vires; (2) do not attempt to make penal an act sanctioned by state law; (3) do not constitute a special law for which there is a general law having uniform operation throughout the state; and (4) do not illegally discriminate between local and nonresident uses of the streets of the city. However, trucks may not be relegated to unsafe streets only. A criminal prosecution will be enjoined when injury to property is threatened. Allison v. Medlock, 224 Ga. 648, 164 S.E. 2d 112 (1968). 

Sec. 13-81. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. 
Deviating truck means a truck which leaves and departs from a truck route while traveling within the city limits. 
Truck means any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property, including raw materials, and whose body weight or whose combined body and load weight exceeds five (5) tons. 
Truck route means any street or portion thereof within the city, over which trucks are not prohibited to operate by the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 7-12-88(1), § II) 
Sec. 13-82. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to protect the public safety in the use of the streets of the city; to facilitate and expedite traffic within the city; and to protect the streets of the city from unusual wear and damage. 
(Ord. of 7-12-88(1), § I) 
Sec. 13-83. - Application of regulations. 
(a)  All streets within the city except those listed in subsection (b) below are closed to truck traffic. 
(b)  The following are excepted from the provisions of subsection (a) above: 
(1)  Any truck may be deviated from a truck route and operated over a street listed herein where necessary to reach a destination point within the city for the conduct of business, provided streets upon which truck traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection of the street nearest such destination. 
(2)  Any truck may be operated over any city street listed herein where necessary to leave a point of origin within the city for the conduct of business, provided it leaves such street at the nearest intersection of a truck route to such point of origin. 
(3)  Any truck may be operated over any street listed herein if owned or operated by the city, public utilities, any contractor or material man, while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements, or street utilities within the city. 
(4)  MARTA bus routes: See section 13-25. 
(Ord. of 7-12-88(1), § III) 
Sec. 13-84. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The chief of police shall cause the city limits to be clearly sign-posted to give notice that this article is in effect. 
(b)  The chief of police shall have the authority to require any person driving or in control of any commercial vehicle not proceeding over a truck route or street over which truck traffic is permitted to proceed to any public or private scale available for the purpose of weighing and determining whether this article has been complied with. 
(Ord. of 7-12-88(1), § IV) 
Cross reference— Police, ch. 21. 
Secs. 13-85—13-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BUSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 13-106. - Passenger buses generally. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle, overtaking any passenger bus stopped or about to stop for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers, shall stop such vehicle at least six (6) feet to the rear of the bus and keep same stationary until any such passengers have disembarked and reached a place of safety, or boarded such car or bus as the case may be. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to alight from or board any bus while same is yet in movement. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride on any portion of any bus which has not been provided and designated for that purpose. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1005) 
Secs. 13-107—13-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MARTA BUSES 

Sec. 13-121. - Title. 
This division shall be known as "The City of Stone Mountain Ordinance Regulating MARTA Buses". 
(Ord. of 2-3-87, § I) 
Sec. 13-122. - Unscheduled and unauthorized stops, and leaving the bus unsecured. 
(a)  Before leaving the bus, the operator must set the parking brake firmly and make sure that it holds, place gear lever in neutral position and cut the engine off. If bus is on the slightest hill, the operator must set the front wheels to the curb. 
(b)  Under no circumstances is the rear interlock on the bus to be used in place of the parking brake. 
(c)  It is not permissible for an operator to leave his bus at any point along the route while passengers are still on the bus and keep the passengers waiting while he is eating a meal in a restaurant or transacting personal business. 
(d)  If it is necessary to leave the bus for any reason, the door must be closed. 
(Ord. of 2-3-87, § II) 
Sec. 13-123. - Engine running on long layovers. 
Operators are required to cut their bus engines off with layovers in excess of eight (8) minutes, except when the temperature is below twenty (20) degrees Fahrenheit or above ninety (90) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Ord. of 2-3-87, § III) 
Sec. 13-124. - Unauthorized parking. 
Buses must park in authorized areas with the exception of the following: 
(1)  Between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 8:30 a.m. one (1) bus will be allowed to park at each of the below locations: 
a.  5347 E. Mountain Street. 
b.  5401 E. Mountain Street (in front of bank) 
(2)  Between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:30 a.m. one (1) bus will be allowed to park at the below location: 
a.  5379 E. Mountain Street (old post office). 
(3)  If businesses at any location set forth above are open, the bus shall not park there, and if asked or ordered by a law enforcement officer to move, the operator must do so. 
(Ord. of 2-3-87, § III) 
Sec. 13-125. - Routes. 
The following descriptions of MARTA bus routes shall be attached to the route 120 weekday, Saturday and Sunday run cards: 
  

 
(Ord. of 3-28-88; Ord. of 5-23-88; Ord. of 7-12-88(1), App. A) 
Sec. 13-126. - Series restrictions. 
MARTA buses in the 1600 series are prohibited within the city limits. 
(Ord. of 11-1-88(2); Ord. of 12-13-88) 
Secs. 13-127—13-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BICYCLES, GOLF CARTS, AND SIMILAR VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-02, adopted June 5, 2012, amended the Code by repealing former art. VI, §§ 13-136—13-142, and adding a new art. VI. Former art. VI pertained to bicycles, and derived from an ordinance of April 7, 1987 and an ordinance of July 7, 1987. 

Sec. 13-136. - Short title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as "Bicycles, Golf Carts, and Similar Vehicles Ordinance of the City of Stone Mountain." 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, 6-5-12) 
Sec. 13-137. - Findings; definitions; general restrictions. 
(a)  Findings. The mayor and city council find that all public streets, sidewalks and paved recreational paths located within the city's territorial boundaries and under its jurisdiction are designed and constructed so as to safely permit the use of the streets. Low speed vehicles are limited to public streets. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  All-terrain vehicle means any motorized vehicle designed for off-road use which is equipped with three (3) or more low-pressure tires and with a seat to be straddled by the operator and with handlebars for steering control. 
(2)  Bicycle means every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having only two (2) wheels which are in tandem and either of which is more than thirteen (13) inches in diameter. 
(3)  Dealer means a person engaged in the business of buying, selling, or exchanging vehicles who has an established place of business in this state. 
(4)  Electric bicycle means a device with two (2) or three (3) wheels which has a saddle and fully operative pedals for human propulsion and also has an electric motor. For such a device to be considered an electric assisted bicycle, it shall meet the requirements of the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards, as set forth in 49 CFR 571 et seq., and shall operate in such a manner that the electric motor disengages or ceases to function when the brakes are applied. The electric motor in an electric assisted bicycle shall: 
a.  Have a power output of not more than one thousand (1,000) watts; 
b.  Be incapable of propelling the device at a speed of more than twenty (20) miles per hour on level ground; and 
c.  Be incapable of further increasing the speed of the device when human power alone is used to propel the device at or more than twenty (20) miles per hour. 
(5)  Electric personal assistive mobility device (EPAMD) means a self-balancing, two (2) non-tandem wheeled device designed to transport only one (1) person and having an electric propulsion system with average power of seven hundred fifty (750) watts (one (1) horsepower) and a maximum speed of less than twenty (20) miles per hour on a paved level surface when powered solely by such propulsion system and ridden by an operator who weighs one hundred seventy (170) pounds. 
(6)  Gross weight means the weight of a vehicle without load plus the weight of any load thereon. 
(7)  Low-speed motor vehicle (LSMV) means any four-wheeled electric vehicle whose top speed attainable in one mile is greater than twenty (20) miles per hour but not greater than twenty-five (25) miles per hour on a paved level surface and which is manufactured in compliance with those federal motor vehicle safely standards for low-speed vehicles set forth in 49 CFR 571.500 and in effect on January 1, 2001. 
(8)  Moped means a motor driven cycle equipped with two (2) or three (3) wheels, with or without foot pedals to permit muscular propulsion, and an independent power source providing a maximum of two (2) brake horsepower. If a combustion engine is used, the maximum piston or rotor displacement shall be three and five-hundredths (3.05) cubic inches (fifty (50) cubic centimeters) regardless of the number of chambers in such power source. The power source shall be capable of propelling the vehicle unassisted, at a speed not to exceed thirty (30) miles per hour (48.28 kilometers per hour) on level road surface and shall be equipped with a power drive system that functions directly or automatically only, not requiring clutching or shifting by the operator after the drive system is engaged. 
(9)  Motor driven cycle means every motorcycle, including every motor scooter, with a motor which produces not to exceed five (5) brake horsepower, every bicycle with a motor attached, and every moped. 
(10)  Motorcycle means every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor, all-terrain vehicle, dirt bike, and moped. 
(11)  Motorized cart or golf cart means every motor vehicle having no less than three (3) wheels and an unladen weight of one thousand three hundred (1,300) pounds or less and which cannot operate at more than twenty (20) miles per hour. 
(12)  Motorized play vehicle means a coaster, scooter, pocket bike, any other alternatively fueled device, or other motorized vehicle that is self-propelled by a motor engine, gas or electric, and is not otherwise defined as a motorized cart, low-speed motor vehicle (LSMV), motorcycle, electric assisted bicycle, motorized skateboard, electric personal assistive mobility device or motorized wheelchair. 
(13)  Motorized skateboard means a self-propelled device, including Segways, that has a motor, gas or electric, a deck upon which a person may ride, not equipped with a seat, and at least two (2) tandem wheels in contact with the ground and which is not otherwise defined in this Code as a motor vehicle, motorcycle, motorized play vehicle, motor scooter, electric personal assistive mobility device or motorized wheelchair. 
(14)  Motorized wheelchair means a self-propelled wheelchair that is used by a physically disabled person for mobility. 
(15)  Pocket motorcycle or pocket bike means a two-wheeled vehicle other than a motor vehicle, bicycle with helper motor or a motorized scooter and which is propelled by an internal combustion engine, electric motor or other mechanical means, is capable of carrying a rider and/or passenger at a speed in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour, and is designed to replicate the general appearance of a motorcycle, regardless of the scale of the replication. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, 6-5-12) 
Sec. 13-138. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates the terms of the article shall be punished as provided in section 1-11, Code of Ordinances, City of Stone Mountain. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, 6-5-12) 
Sec. 13-139. - Liability and insurance. 
(a)  Each person using the streets, sidewalks, or recreation paths is liable for his own actions. 
(b)  Owners of motorized (golf) carts shall maintain liability insurance on any cart that is to be operated on the streets and recreational paths of this city. The level of insurance coverage shall be at least the minimum required for motor vehicles in this state. Nothing in this article shall be construed to require insurance coverage on motorized carts used solely on private property. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, 6-5-12; Ord. No. 2012-05, 10-2-12) 
Sec. 13-140. - Equipment. 
(a)  A low speed vehicle must be equipped with headlamps, stop lamps, turn signal lamps, tail lamps, reflex reflectors, parking brakes, rearview mirrors, windshields, and a vehicle identification number. Low speed vehicles not meeting these requirements are prohibited from operating within the territorial boundaries of the city. 
(b)  Motorized (golf) carts that are operated on the roadways and recreational paths of the city shall be equipped with headlamps, tail lamps, brake lamps, turn signals, a rear view mirror, horn and a windshield. It is further recommended that additional reflective or illuminative devices, such as reflective tape or running lights, be placed on the sides of motorized (golf) carts that are driven before sunrise and after sunset. These equipment requirements are a minimum and are in addition to any requirement established by state law or promulgated by the state commissioner of public safety. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, 6-5-12; Ord. No. 2012-05, 10-2-12) 
Sec. 13-141. - Registration; inspection. 
(a)  Registration and annual inspection required. Owners of any electric or gasoline-powered motorized (golf) cart that is to be operated over the designated streets, areas, or paths of the city must register the vehicle within ten (10) days of purchase with the city police department. Registrant must provide the police department with name and address of owner, vehicle manufacturer, model, vehicle identification number, color, and proof of ownership and insurance. Upon completion and police inspection of the cart to ensure compliance with all parts of this article, the police department shall issue two (2) decals as proof of inspection to the vehicle owner. Decals shall be affixed to the front and rear of the motorized (golf) cart and shall remain valid until January 31 of the following calendar year. 
(b)  Inspection fees. An annual inspection fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) will be assessed for motorized (golf) carts belonging to a resident or business owner of the city. Non-residents or business owners located outside the city shall be assessed an annual inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each motorized (golf) cart. 
(c)  Disabled parking. Motorized (golf) carts may utilize parking designated as disabled parking provided that a permit issued under O.C.G.A. § 40-2-74.1 is displayed about the cart and the actual disabled person is the current driver or a passenger of the cart. Violations of this requirement may be prosecuted under O.C.G.A. § 40-6-226. 
(d)  Rental golf carts. Golf cart dealers and distributors, as well as other commercial establishments, may rent golf carts to the public for use on the streets and recreation paths of the city. Each such establishment renting golf carts shall be required to register each and shall maintain a written record of each person renting a golf cart. Renters shall be required to furnish positive identification and shall be furnished a copy of this article to read. Each renter must be at least sixteen (16) years of age and possess a valid driver's license. Golf carts for temporary use by the city or other organizations as part of managing special events are exempt from the requirements of this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, 6-5-12; Ord. No. 2012-05, 10-2-12) 
Sec. 13-142. - Operation regulations. 
(a)  Only those persons who hold a valid motor vehicle driver's license may drive a golf cart on the streets or recreational paths of the city. Exception: Those persons who are fifteen (15) years of age or older but do not hold a valid motor vehicle driver's license may drive a golf cart on designated streets and recreation paths of the city if they are accompanied in the front seat by a person at least eighteen (18) years of age who holds a valid motor vehicle driver's license. 
(b)  Low-speed vehicles may be operated on public streets within the city limits. The operator of a low-speed vehicle shall not operate such vehicle on any highway where the posted speed limit exceeds twenty-five (25) miles per hour. No all-terrain vehicles (ATVs), regardless of power source, are permitted to operate on city streets or recreation paths. Low-speed vehicles may be operated on private property with the permission of the owner. 
(c)  A motorized cart or golf cart may be operated on any public street except as prohibited by ordinance and on all paved recreational paths located within the territorial boundaries of the city. This does not prohibit golf carts from crossing any road or street at properly marked intersections. 
(d)  No person under the age of fifteen (15) years shall be permitted to drive a low-speed vehicle or a golf cart on the streets or recreation paths of the city under any circumstance. 
(e)  All golf cart operators shall abide by all traffic regulations applicable to vehicular traffic when using the streets and recreation paths of the city. All golf cart operators are required to use available recreation paths in preference to city streets. 
(f)  Low-speed vehicles operating on city streets shall comply with all local and state traffic laws and may be cited for traffic violations in the same manner as motor vehicles. 
(g)  Golf carts may not be operated on sidewalks. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any low-speed vehicle or golf cart or for any other person operating, employing, or permitting the use of, or otherwise directing the use of such vehicle, to operate or permit the operator of any such vehicle to drive over the streets or recreation paths in violation of this article. 
(i)  Authorized users of sidewalks are as follows: 
(1)  Pedestrians. 
(2)  Non-motorized vehicles. 
(3)  Roller skates, roller blades and skateboarders (thirty (30) minutes before sunrise to thirty (30) minutes after sunset). 
(4)  Emergency and authorized maintenance vehicles. 
(5)  Motorized wheelchairs. 
(6)  Bicycles. 
(7)  Electric personal assistive mobility device. 
(8)  Public safety vehicles. 
(j)  Every person operating a bicycle shall strictly observe all traffic signs and signals and all other traffic rules and regulations, and shall obey the orders and directions of every officer of the city authorized to direct or regulate traffic. 
(k)  Seating on motorized (golf) carts. When a cart is in motion, all occupants of a motorized cart must be seated. No rider shall stand or be seated in the lap of another rider. 
(l)  Motorized (golf) carts that are operated at any time from a half-hour before sunset to a half-hour after sunrise and at any time when it is raining and at any other time when there is not sufficient visibility to render clearly discernible persons and vehicles on the roadway at a distance of five hundred (500) feet ahead and behind shall have headlamps and tail lamps illuminated. 
(m)  The use of motorized or golf carts complying with all guidelines set forth in this article shall be permitted on any city street for which the speed limit is twenty-five (25) mph or less, unless otherwise prohibited. Such a cart is permitted to cross a street of higher speed limit if traveling from one (1) permitted street to another. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, 6-5-12; Ord. No. 2012-05, 10-2-12; Ord. No. 2017-01, pt. I, 2-1-17) 
Sec. 13-143. - Prohibited. 
Prohibited users of recreation paths and sidewalks are as follows: 
(1)  Automobiles and trucks (except authorized maintenance vehicles). 
(2)  Motorcycles. 
(3)  Horses, mules or donkeys. 
(4)  Low-speed vehicles. 
(5)  Unregistered electric golf carts. 
(6)  Unregistered gas golf carts. 
(7)  Go-carts. 
(8)  Minibikes and mopeds. 
(9)  All-terrain vehicles. 
(10)  Motorized play vehicles. 
(11)  Street and trail motorized bikes or vehicles (not to include electric bicycles). 
(12)  Pocket motorcycle or pocket bike. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, 6-5-12) 
Sec. 13-144. - Hazardous activities and special rules. 
(a)  Sidewalks and recreation paths are for transportation and public recreation by various groups of permitted users. No individual or group shall engage in hazardous activities on the streets and recreational paths. Such hazardous activities and the special rules pertaining to them include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Racing of any form, except for special events approved by the city; and 
(2)  Blocking of public access, except for special events approved by the city. 
(b)  None of the prohibited users in section 13-143 shall use the sidewalks or recreational paths for any purpose whatsoever. 
(c)  Normal rules of the road shall apply to the recreation paths. For instance, when approaching oncoming path users, each user shall move to his right side of the path. Passing shall be on the left side of the path. 
(d)  Pedestrians should be given due consideration and reasonable right-of-way by other users of the sidewalks and recreation paths to ensure safe passage. 
(e)  A warning or announcement shall be given by operators of golf carts and other users of the recreation paths, i.e., bicyclists or skaters when approaching pedestrians from the rear. This warning or announcement may be verbal, but it is recommended that bicyclists and golf cart operators equip their vehicles with a warning device such as a horn or bell. Each user of the recreation path~ shall be considerate of the safety and welfare of the other users and dangerous conduct will not be tolerated. 
(f)  All laws and ordinances relative to alcohol or illegal drugs and their use, including open container laws that apply to traffic on the streets of the city, also apply to the sidewalks and recreation paths. 
(g)  All litter shall be deposited in the receptacles provided along the sidewalks and recreation paths or retained by the user for proper disposal later. Littering on the sidewalks or recreation paths or the areas adjacent to the sidewalk or path shall be subject penalties described in section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, 6-5-12) 
Secs. 13-145—13-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SKATES; SKATEBOARDS; SCOOTERS 

Sec. 13-166. - Short title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as "Skates, Skateboards and Scooters Ordinance of the City of Stone Mountain." 
(Ord. of 8-4-87(4), § I) 
Sec. 13-167. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Scooter means a vehicle consisting of a board mounted on two (2) tandem wheels and steered by a long handle attached to the front axle; the rider stands with one (1) foot on the board, using the other foot to push. 
Skates means a keel-shaped metal runner attached to a plate or frame, with suitable clamps or straps for fastening it to the sole of a boot or shoe. 
Skateboard means a wooden, plastic or metal support attached to wheels capable of rolling on flat surfaces, or similar shaped device. 
(Ord. of 8-4-87(4), § II) 
Sec. 13-168. - Use of sidewalks, streets. 
Persons upon skates, skateboards, scooters or similar type devices shall not travel by such means upon the sidewalks of the central business district of the city, or any public street within the city or any publicly-owned property. 
(Ord. of 8-4-87(4), § III) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 25. 
Sec. 13-169. - Enforcement. 
The chief of police shall enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 8-4-87(4), § IV) 
Cross reference— Police, ch. 21. 
Secs. 13-170—13-190. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IX. - REDLIGHT CAMERA ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 13-195. - Title. 
For convenience in reference, this article shall be entitled "The Red-Light Camera Enforcement Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. I, 9-19-05) 
Sec. 13-196. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to enhance public safety through the use of technologies which reduce the violation of red traffic signals. 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. I, 9-19-05) 
Sec. 13-197. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
In operation means operating in good working condition. 
Operator shall mean any individual driving and/or possession of a vehicle. 
Owner means the registered owner of a motor vehicle, except that such term shall not include a motor vehicle company when a motor vehicle registered by such company is being operated by another person under a rental agreement with such company. 
Recorded image means images recorded by a traffic-control signal monitoring device: 
(1)  With: 
a.  Not less than two (2) photographs. 
b.  Not less than two (2) microphoto- graphs. 
c.  Not less than two (2) electronic images. 
d.  Videotape. 
(2)  Showing a traffic-control signal displaying a circular red or red arrow signal along with the rear of a motor vehicle apparently operated in disregard or disobedience of such signal and, on at least one (1) image or portion of tape, clearly depicting the number or other identifying designation of the license plate displayed on the motor vehicle. 
(3)  A picture of the operator shall be taken, and may be introduced as evidence of the identity of the operator of the vehicle. 
Signature means any manual or facsimile of a person's signature. 
System location is the approach to an intersection toward which a photographic, video digital or electronic camera is directed and is in operation. 
Traffic-control signal monitoring device means a device with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a traffic-control signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles being operated in disregard or disobedience of a circular red or red arrow signal. 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. I, 9-19-05) 
Sec. 13-198. - Monetary penalty. 
(a)  Vehicular traffic facing a steady circular red signal alone shall stop at a clearly marked stop line or, if there is no stop line, before entering the crosswalk on the nearside of the intersection or, if there is no crosswalk, before entering the intersection, and shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown by a steady circular green signal. 
(b)  Vehicular traffic facing a steady red arrow signal indication shall stop at a clearly marked stop line or, if there is no stop line, before entering the crosswalk of the nearside of the intersection, or if there is no crosswalk, before entering the intersection, and shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown by a steady green arrow signal indication. 
(c)  The driver of a motor vehicle shall be liable for a civil monetary penalty imposed pursuant to this article if such motor vehicle is found, as evidenced by information obtained from a traffic-control signal monitoring device, to have failed to comply with a traffic light signal within the city limits as designated in subsections 13-198(a) and (b) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. I, 9-19-05) 
Sec. 13-199. - Proof; certificate. 
(a)  Proof that a particular vehicle entered an intersection in violation of subsection 13-198(a) or (b) of the City of Stone Mountain City Code, as detected by a traffic-control signal monitoring device, together with proof that the particular vehicle is registered with the state department of public safety (or any other state or local vehicle registration office) in the charged person's name, shall raise the evidentiary presumption and constitute prima facie evidence in any prosecution of a violation of that section that the charged person was the person driving the vehicle depicted in the recorded image. 
(b)  A certificate, sworn to or affirmed by a trained law enforcement officer or a technician employed by the city police department, or a copy thereof, based on inspection of recorded images produced by a traffic-control signal monitoring device shall be considered prima facie evidence of the facts contained therein. 
(c)  Recorded images made for the purpose of this subsection shall not be a public record. 
(d)  The provisions of this article shall not limit law enforcement agencies to the use of traffic-control signal monitoring devices in enforcing O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(a); and, when there is evidence obtained from other source or sources which constitutes a prima facie case or a violation of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(a), such violation may be prosecuted as otherwise provide by law in lieu of, but not in addition to, enforcement under this article. 
(e)  Such presumption shall be rebutted if the owner or lessee of the vehicle files a sworn notarized statement with the city police department or other city agency designated by the city manager prior to the return date established on the citation identifying the name and address of the operator of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation. Upon review of the notarized statement by the appropriate city employee, a hearing may be set for prosecution of the alleged violation. 
(f)  Such presumption shall be rebutted if the charged person can prove that they were not the operator of the vehicle through photographic evidence produced and maintained by the city when the vehicle owned by the charged person was in violation of section 13-198(a) or (b) of the City of Stone Mountain City Code. 
(g)  Such presumption shall be rebutted if the owner or lessee of the vehicle testifies under oath in open court or other appropriate administrative hearing that he or she was not the operator of the vehicle at the time of alleged violation. 
(h)  Such presumption shall be rebutted if a certified copy of a police report, showing that the vehicle had been reported to the police as stolen prior to the time of the alleged violation, is present, prior to the return date established on the citation issued pursuant to this section, to the court adjudicating the alleged violation. Upon review of the notarized statement by the prosecuting attorney for the city, a hearing may be set for prosecution of the alleged violation. 
(i)  Such presumption shall be rebutted if the recorded image depicts the vehicle passed through the intersection in violation of section 13-198(a) or (b) of the City of Stone Mountain City Code as part of a funeral procession. 
(j)  Such presumption shall be rebutted if the recorded image depicts the vehicle passed through the intersection in violation of section 13-198(a) or (b) of the City of Stone Mountain City Code in order to avoid impeding the efforts of an emergency vehicle to pass through the intersection. 
(k)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained here, the prosecution and conviction for a violation of this article shall not require a picture of the driver described in section 13-197(f)(iii) above. 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. I, 9-19-05) 
Sec. 13-200. - Penalty; effect of a conviction. 
(a)  Imposition of a penalty pursuant to this section shall not be deemed a criminal conviction as an operator and shall not be made a part of the operating record of the person upon whom such liability is imposed nor shall it be used for insurance purposes in the provision of motor vehicle insurance coverage. The civil monetary penalty imposed by this section for each violation shall be no greater than seventy dollars ($70.00). 
(b)  Upon a failure to respond to any notice of violation by the prescribed date, the notice shall be considered a judgment and shall carry interest at the legal rate. 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. I, 9-19-05) 
Sec. 13-201. - Summons. 
(a)  A summons for a violation of this section may be executed by the city by sending by first class mail, a copy thereof to the address of the owner or lessee of the vehicle shown, in the case of vehicle owners, in the records of the state department of public safety (or any other state vehicle registration office) or, in the case of vehicle lessees or renters, in the records of the lessor. Said summons shall be postmarked not later than ten (10) days after the date of the alleged violation. 
(b)  No proceedings for contempt or arrest shall be instituted for failure to appear on the return date of the summons. 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. I, 9-19-05) 
Sec. 13-202. - Private entities. 
(a)  A private entity may enter into an agreement with the city to be compensated for providing the traffic light signal violation monitoring system or equipment and all related support services, to include consulting, operations and administration. However, only a trained law enforcement officer or a technician employed by the city police department may swear to or affirm the certificate required by 13-199(b) of this section. 
(b)  No portion of any fine collected through the use of a traffic-control signal monitoring device may be paid to the manufacturer or vendor. Compensation to the manufacturer or vendor shall be based on the value of such equipment and shall not be based on the number of traffic citations issued or the revenue generated by traffic-control signal monitoring devices. 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. I, 9-19-05) 
Sec. 13-203. - Signage. 
(a)  The city shall erect signs on every highway which comprises a part of the state highway system at that point on the highway which intersects the jurisdictional limits to the city. A sign shall be erected also by the city on each public road on the approach to the next traffic-control signal-monitoring device which is monitoring such next signal for such road. 
(b)  Such signs shall be at least thirty (30) inches by thirty (30) inches in measurements and shall warn motorists that traffic-control monitoring devices are being employed. 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. I, 9-19-05) 
Sec. 13-204. - Warning period. 
Only warning notices and not citations shall be sent during the thirty-day period commencing on the date of each installation of a traffic-control monitoring device. 
(Ord. No. 05-17, pt. I, 9-19-05) 
Chapter 14 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Judicial branch, Art. V. 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Constitution reference— General rights of defendants, Art. I, § I, Par. XIV; judicial power of the state, Art. VI, § I, Par. I; effect of constitution on municipal courts, Art. VI, § 10, Par. I. 
State Law reference— Municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-1. - Warrants. 
Any person having knowledge of the commission of a criminal offense may file a written verified complaint with the municipal court. If the court is satisfied that the violation has been committed and that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the defendant committed the violation, an arrest warrant shall be issued. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1001) 
Sec. 14-2. - Forfeiture of bond. 
If a defendant under bond does not appear when his name is called, and no continuance has been granted, then his bond shall be forfeited. Whether or not the defendant has been released on his own recognizance, a warrant of arrest may be issued. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1002) 
Sec. 14-3. - Minors, notice to parents upon arrest. 
Upon the arrest of any person under the age of eighteen (18), the clerk shall notify the parent or guardian informing him of the nature of the charge and the date the case will be heard. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1003) 
Sec. 14-4. - Acceptance of pleas. 
Before accepting a plea to an offense charged, the municipal court shall in all cases, in language in which the defendant can understand, inform him of the nature of the charge against him and the penalty which may be imposed upon conviction, and shall inform the defendant of his fundamental constitutional rights. The fundamental constitutional rights should include, but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  That he is not required to make any statement and that anything said by him may be used against him; 
(2)  That he may have a lawyer; 
(3)  That he may have his case delayed to give him sufficient time to be advised by a lawyer; 
(4)  That he may have a lawyer present during any questioning and proceeding; 
(5)  That he may testify in his own behalf; 
(6)  That he may appeal any final decision rendered by the court; 
(7)  That a record of any conviction will become a part of his permanent record; 
(8)  That he may be admitted to bail in appropriate cases; 
(9)  That he is innocent until proven guilty; 
(10)  That he may have the complaining or material witness present and the right to cross-examine; and 
(11)  That he may bring witnesses in his own behalf. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1004) 
Sec. 14-5. - Pleas. 
(a)  The defendant shall enter one (1) of the following pleas: 
(1)  Guilty; 
(2)  Not guilty; 
(3)  Nolo contendere (with the permission of the court); or 
(4)  A former judgment of conviction or acquittal of the offense charged. 
(b)  If the defendant refuses to enter a plea, the municipal court shall enter a plea of not guilty for him and set the case down for trial. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1005) 
Sec. 14-6. - Disposition of cases. 
Except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance, all prosecutions docketed at a designated session of the municipal court shall be disposed of during that particular session. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1006) 
Sec. 14-7. - Continuance of cases. 
Only the judge or other officer presiding shall have the authority to continue the case. No continuance shall be allowed except for good cause shown. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1007) 
Sec. 14-8. - Appearance of complaining witnesses. 
A material or complaining witness in any contested prosecution shall appear at the session at which the prosecution is docketed. The prosecution may be dismissed if the material witness fails to appear. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1008) 
Sec. 14-9. - Rules of evidence. 
The general rules of evidence shall be applicable in the trial of all cases. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1009) 
Sec. 14-10. - Judgment and sentences. 
Upon a verdict or plea of guilty and after announcing the judgment, the municipal court shall impose sentence. The court may: 
(1)  Impose a fine, with or without a commitment for confinement and/or forced labor; 
(2)  Commit such person for confinement and/or forced labor; 
(3)  Suspend the execution of the sentence in whole or in part; or 
(4)  Defer the execution of the sentence or any portion or portions thereof to one (1) or more fixed dates in the future. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1010) 
Sec. 14-11. - Parole. 
The mayor shall have the authority to parole on good conduct persons convicted in the municipal court of violating the laws and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1011) 
Sec. 14-12. - Certiorari. 
Any person convicted in the municipal court shall have the right to certiorari as provided in section 5.14 of the charter. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1012) 
Sec. 14-13. - Associate judge. 
(a)  There is hereby established the position of associate judge in the municipal court of the city. 
(b)  The associate judge shall be appointed annually by the city council and shall serve at the pleasure of the city council. 
(c)  The associate judge shall be compensated in an amount to be determined by the city council and fixed by ordinance. 
(d)  Qualifications of such associate judge, removal from office and the oath of office shall be the same as those provisions for the municipal court judge in section 5.11 of the city charter. 
(Ord. of 2-1-94) 
Sec. 14-14. - Chief judge, appointment, compensation. 
(a)  There is hereby established the position of chief judge in the municipal court of the city. 
(b)  The chief judge shall be appointed annually by the city council and shall serve at the pleasure of the city council. 
(c)  The chief judge shall be compensated in an amount to be determined by the city council and fixed by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 99-3, Pt. 1, 3-2-99) 
Chapter 15 - NOISE CONTROL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 07-07, adopted August 7, 2007, amended the Code by repealing former ch. 15, §§ 15-1—15-11, and adding a new ch. 15. Former ch. 15 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from an Ord. of April 7, 1987, and Ord. No. 97-10, adopted July 8, 1997. 
Charter reference— Municipal powers, § 1.12. 
Cross reference— Animals, ch. 4; buildings, ch. 5; cemeteries, ch. 6; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 13; nuisances, ch. 16; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 17; parade and assembly, ch. 18; parks and recreation, ch. 19. 
State Law reference— Workers' compensation for loss of hearing caused by harmful noise, O.C.G.A. § 34-9-264; prevention of motor vehicle noise, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-71; nuisances, O.C.G.A. Title 41; noise level of watercraft, O.C.G.A. § 52-7-10. 

Sec. 15-1. - Noise control. 
(a)  Purpose. This section is enacted to protect, preserve and promote the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city through the control of noise. It is the intent of this section to establish standards that will reduce excessive community noises which are harmful and otherwise detrimental to individuals and to the community in the enjoyment of life and property and in the conduct of business. 
(b)  Sound measurement standards for law enforcement personnel. For the purposes of this section, "plainly audible" shall mean any sound emanating from the specific sound-producing sources set forth below which can be heard from the distances set forth below, using the following sound measurement standards: Measurement shall be by the auditory senses of a person standing at a distance no less than the required minimum distance from the source of the sound. For music and other noise, words and phrases need not be discernable. For music and other noise, bass reverberations are included. 
(c)  Prohibited conduct. 
(1)  Restrictions of one hundred (100) feet for 7:00 a.m. through 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and 7:00 a.m. through 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
a.  Mechanical sound-making devices. It is unlawful for any person or persons to play, use, operate, or permit to be played, used, or operated any radio receiving device, television, stereo, musical instrument, phonograph sound amplifier or other machines or devices for the producing, reproducing or amplifying of sound and/or noises at such a volume and in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet or more from the building, structure or vehicle, or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, in which it is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
b.  Human-produced sounds. It is unlawful for any person or persons to yell, shout, hoot, whistle, or sing on the public streets or sidewalks or on private property so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet or more from the place, building, structure, or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, in which the person is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
c.  Commercial advertising. It is unlawful for any person or persons to use, operate, or permit to be used or operated any radio receiving device, musical instrument, phonograph, loud speaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the production or reproduction of sound which is cast upon the public streets or other public property for the purpose of commercial advertising or which serves to attract the attention of the public to any building, structure or vehicle in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet or more from the source of the sound cast upon the public streets or other public property or from the building, structure, or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, in which it is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
d.  Party noise. It is unlawful for any person or persons in charge of a party or other social event that occurs on any private property to allow that party or social event to produce noise in such a manner that such noise is plainly audible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet or more from the building or structure from which the noise is emanating or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, on which the party or social event is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12 midnight on Friday and Saturday. For the purposes of this subsection, a "person in charge of a party or other social event" shall mean any adult person who resides in or on the premises involved in such party or social event and is present at such party or social event. For the purposes of this subsection, "noise" shall mean the same sounds, or any combination thereof, as described in paragraphs a. or b. above. 
(2)  Restrictions of one hundred (100) feet for 11:00 p.m. through 7 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and 12:00 midnight through 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
a.  Mechanical sound-making devices. It is unlawful for any person or persons to play, use, operate, or permit to be played, used, or operated any radio receiving device, television, stereo, musical instrument, phonograph, sound amplifier or other machines or devices for the producing, reproducing or amplifying of sound and/or noise at such a volume and in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet or more from the building, structure, or motor vehicle or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, in which it is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
b.  Human-produced sound. It is unlawful for any person or persons to yell, shout, hoot, whistle or sing on the public streets or sidewalks or on private property so as to create or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet or more from the place on public streets and sidewalks, or in the case of private real property, beyond the property limits, on which the person is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. and on Saturday and Sunday. 
c.  Commercial advertising. It is unlawful for any person or persons to use, operate or permit to be used or operated any radio receiving device, musical instrument, phonograph, loud speaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the production or reproduction of sound which is cast upon the public streets or other public property for the purpose of commercial advertising or which serves to attract the attention of the public to any building, structure or vehicle in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet or more from the source of the sound cast upon the public streets or other public property or from the building, structure, or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, in which it is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
d.  Party noise. It is unlawful for any person or persons in charge of a party or other social event that occurs on any private property to allow that party or event to produce noise in such a manner so as to such noise is plainly audible at a distance or one hundred (100) feet or more from the building or structure from which the party noise is emanating or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, on which the party or social event is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. For the purposes of this subsection, a "person in charge of a party or other social event" shall mean any adult person who resides in or on the premises involved in such party or social event and is present at such party or social event. For the purposes of this subsection, "noise" shall mean the same sounds, or any combination thereof, as described in paragraph a. or b. above. 
(3)  Restrictions for areas within apartments, condominiums, townhouses, duplexes, or other such residential dwelling units. Except for persons within commercial enterprises that have an adjoining property line or boundary with a residential dwelling unit, it is unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any noise in such a manner as to be plainly audible to any other person a distance of five (5) feet beyond the adjoining property line, wall or boundary of any apartment, condominium, townhouse, duplex, or other such residential dwelling units with adjoining points of contact. For the purposes of this subsection, "noise" shall mean human-produced sounds of yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, singing, or mechanically-produced sounds made by a radio-receiving device, television, stereo, musical instrument, phonograph sound amplifier or other machines or devices for the producing, reproducing, or amplifying of sound, or any combination thereof. 
For the purposes of this subsection, "property line or boundary" shall mean an imaginary line drawn through the points of contact of: 
a.  Adjoining apartments, condominiums, townhouse, duplexes or other such residential dwelling units with adjoining points owned, rented, or leased by different persons; or 
b.  Adjoining common areas or adjoining exterior walls. 
Said property line or boundary includes all points of a plane formed by projecting the property line or boundary including the ceiling, the floor, and the walls. 
(4)  Exclusions. The prohibitions of this section shall not apply to the following: 
a.  Noises and/or sounds caused to be made by manufacturing, governmental, construction or commercial entities in the normal course of their business; 
b.  Noises and/or sounds emanating from any official county school event on county school property; 
c.  Noises and/or sounds that are permitted by a special event permit pursuant to provisions of the Code of Ordinances of the city; provided, however, that the producer or coordinator of the special event must comply with the terms, restrictions and conditions of the special event permit; 
d.  Noises or sounds made by domestic animals; 
e.  Noises or sounds made by wireless telecommunication facilities; 
f.  Sound volumes produced by radio, tape player, or other mechanical sound making device or instrument form within a motor vehicle on a street or highway, which sound is controlled by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-14; or 
g.  Noises or sounds made by law enforcement and other public safety officials performing their public functions. 
h.  Sporting events, organized or unorganized using no amplification devices. 
(5)  Time restrictions on use of landscape maintenance motorized devices such as leaf blowers, lawn mowers, or chain saws. It is unlawful for any person to use or operate any noise-generating, motorized landscape maintenance devices, including but not limited to leaf blowers, lawn mowers, or chain saws, within any residential zoning district or in areas within three hundred (300) feet of any residential zoning district from 8:00 p.m. to 8:00 a.m. except that within the agricultural-residential zone no person shall use or operate any such devices within three hundred (300) feet of any residential swelling on adjacent property between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(6)  Registration of outdoor entertainment events. Registration is required of all outdoor entertainment events that have commercial entertainment and/or electronic amplification. Registration of the event must be seventy-two (72) hours prior to the event, and must be by the person or persons responsible for the event. Registration is to be with the city mountain police department, Monday through Friday, from 9:00 a.m. To 4:00 p.m., on an application specified by the chief of police and shall include the organization sponsoring the event, the location, the date and time of the event, and security provisions. Registration shall not be accepted for events that include the hours between 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday, and between 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday mornings. Failure to register may result in a fine or forfeiture of the right of future registrations, or both. Registration does not exempt the person or persons registering the event from ensuring that the event complies with the requirements of this section. Failure to register shall be a violation of this subsection. 
(7)  Penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided by section 1-11 of this Code. 
(8)  Severability clause. A determination of the invalidity or unconstitutionality by a court of competent jurisdiction of any clause, sentence, paragraph, subsection or part of this section shall not affect the validity of the remaining parts of this section. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, 8-7-07; Ord. No. 08-11, 10-7-08) 
Chapter 16 - NUISANCES[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Municipal powers, § 1.12. 
Cross reference— Animals, Ch. 4; buildings, Ch. 5; erosion and sediment control, Ch. 9; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10; health and sanitation, Ch. 11; noise control, Ch. 15; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 17; parades, demonstrations and picketing, Ch. 18; solid waste, Ch. 24; signs constituting nuisance, § 23-9. 
State Law reference— Nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; abatement of nuisances in cities, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. 

Sec. 16-1. - General enumeration. 
The following conditions are declared to be nuisances: 
(1)  Any surface closet or privy upon premises used in connection with a dwelling or place of business; 
(2)  Stagnant water on premises; 
(3)  Any dead or decaying matter, fruit, vegetable, animal or rodent, upon premises which is odorous or capable of causing disease or annoyance to the inhabitants of the city; 
(4)  The generation of smoke or fumes in sufficient amounts to cause odor or annoyance to the inhabitants of the city; 
(5)  The pollution of public water or the injection of matter into the sewerage system which would be damaging thereto; 
(6)  Maintaining a dangerous or diseased animal or fowl; 
(7)  Obstruction of a public street, highway or sidewalk without a permit; 
(8)  Loud or unusual noises which are detrimental or annoying to the public, including without limitation unusual loud disturbances in or to multiple-family complexes such as loud music and other activities in swimming pool and clubhouse areas; and 
(9)  All walls, trees, and buildings that may endanger persons or property. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2001) 
Cross reference— Animals, Ch. 4; sewers, Ch. 22; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 25. 
Sec. 16-2. - Complaint. 
Any official or inhabitant of the city may direct a complaint of nuisance to the mayor. The mayor, upon finding that a nuisance does exist, shall issue notice to the owner, agent in control of, or tenant in possession, stating that a nuisance has been found to exist and issuing an order that the nuisance be abated within so many hours or days as the mayor shall deem reasonable, having consideration for the nature of the nuisance and its effect on the public. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2002) 
Sec. 16-3. - Abatement by city. 
In any case where the owner, agent or tenant fails to abate the nuisance in the time specified, or where the owner, agent or tenant cannot be served with notice, or where the nature of the nuisance is such, in the opinion of the mayor, that it must be immediately abated, the mayor may issue an order to the chief of police directing him to cause the nuisance to be abated. The chief of police, in such case, shall keep a record of the expenses and cost of abating same, and execution shall be issued against the owner, agent or tenant for the amount of the cost. The execution shall be enforced in the same manner as executions in favor of the city are levied and collected and shall be a lien on the property whereon the nuisance was abated until such time as fully satisfied. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2003) 
Sec. 16-4. - Failure to abate an offense. 
It is hereby declared to be an offense for any owner, agent or tenant to fail to abate a nuisance within the time specified after an order has been served upon him. Each day a nuisance is continued shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2004) 
Chapter 17 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Municipal powers, § 1.12. 
Cross reference— Health and sanitation, ch. 11; noise control, ch. 15; nuisances, ch. 16; parade and assembly, ch. 18. 
State Constitution reference— Limitations on special legislation, art. III, § VI, par. IV. 
State Law reference— Crimes and offenses, O.C.G.A. Title 16; adoption of ordinances, etc., O.C.G.A. § 36-35-3; limitations on home rule powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6; abatement of nuisances in cities, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Aiding arrests. 
No person in the city between the ages of eighteen (18) and fifty (50) years, upon being duly summoned by the police or any member of the city council to aid in suppressing an affray, breach of the peace, or other outrage shall refuse or neglect to arrest, or aid in arresting any offenders. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1015) 
State Law reference— Compensation of persons for injuries sustained while preventing crime or aiding officers of the law, O.C.G.A. § 28-5-100 et seq. 
Sec. 17-2. - Disorderly conduct. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to act in a violent, loud, turbulent, quarrelsome, boisterous, indecent or disorderly manner or to disturb the good order, morals or dignity of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1001) 
Cross reference— Protection of sewage works from damage, § 22-3. 
State Law reference— Offenses against public order, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-30 et seq. 
Sec. 17-3. - Permitting disorderly conduct in place of business. 
No person shall permit any disruption of order in any store or other place of business that caters to the public to the annoyance or disturbance of the neighborhood. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1002) 
Cross reference— Licenses and business regulations, ch. 12. 
State Law reference— Maintaining a disorderly house, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-44. 
Sec. 17-4. - Public disturbance. 
No person shall congregate in or around any public place, schoolhouse or public entertainment, in such a disorderly or rude manner as to become offensive to those attending the church, auditorium or public place, by loud talking, whistling or otherwise. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1003) 
State Law reference— Preventing or disrupting lawful meetings, gatherings or processions, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34. 
Sec. 17-5. - Sleeping in public places, on private premises. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sleep on or at the foot of the stairway of any building, sidewalk or alleys of the city or on public grounds, or on the private premises of any person without the consent of such person or the persons having control thereof. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1004) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 25. 
State Law reference— Criminal trespass, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-21. 
Sec. 17-6. - Remaining in front of public place. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, after having been directed by any officer or member of the police force to move away therefrom, to remain in front of any church or other place of public worship during services therein, or in front of any depot, theater, concert hall, ballroom, clubhouse, cafe or lunch room, drug store, or other place, or on the public thoroughfares of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1005) 
Cross reference— Licenses and business regulations, ch. 12. 
State Law reference— Unlawful assembly, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-33. 
Sec. 17-7. - Sleeping in parked automobile or truck. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sleep in any parked automobile or truck in the city after 10:00 p.m. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1006) 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 13. 
State Law reference— Entering vehicle for criminal purposes, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-1. 
Sec. 17-8. - Discharging firearms. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any air rifle or firearm, such as pistols, shot guns, rifles, machine guns, dynamite caps, cannons, artillery, or other explosives within the corporate limits of the city unless: in defense of person, or habitation; by an officer engaged in the discharge of his official duties; by person or persons engaged in military duties including military burials; or the discharge of small arms (pistols or rifles only) as part of a permitted ceremonial event. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1014; Ord. No. 2010-09, 8-3-10) 
State Law reference— Discharge of firearms, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-103 et seq. 
Sec. 17-9. - Occupying place of prostitution. 
No person shall occupy any house or any portion of a house to be used as a place of prostitution. 
(Code 1976, § 10-3001) 
State Law reference— Prostitution offenses, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-9 et seq. 
Sec. 17-10. - Criminal trespass by motor vehicle.
