A person commits the offense of criminal trespass by motor vehicle when the person, after having been requested not to do so by a law enforcement officer or by the owner or an authorized agent of the owner, parks or stands an occupied or unoccupied motor vehicle in, or repeatedly drives a motor vehicle through or within, a parking area which is located on privately-owned property and is provided by a merchant, a group of merchants, or a shopping center or other similar facility for customers if: 
(1)  The parking area is identified by at least one (1) sign as specified in this paragraph, and if the parking area contains more than one hundred fifty (150) parking spaces then by at least one (1) such sign for every one hundred fifty (150) parking spaces, each such sign containing the following information in easy to read printing: 
a.  Notice of the elements of the crime of criminal trespass by motor vehicles; 
b.  Identification of the property which is reserved for customer's use only; 
c.  Identification of the merchants, or shopping center or other similar facility providing the parking area; and 
d.  Warning that violators will be prosecuted; and 
(2)  The motor vehicle is parked, is standing, or is being operated other than for the purpose of: 
a.  Transporting some person to or from the interior of the place of business of a merchant identified by the sign or signs in the parking area or to or from the interior of the shopping center or other facility so identified; 
b.  Making use of a telephone, vending machine, automatic teller machine, or other similar facility located in the parking area; 
c.  Carrying out an activity for which express permission has been given by the owner of the parking area or an authorized representative of the owner. 
(Ord. of 4-4-89, § 1) 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 13. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-29. 
Sec. 17-11. - Public indecency prohibited. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of public indecency when he or she performs any of the following acts in a place where a person should reasonably expect to be in view of the public: 
(1)  Exposure of the genitals; 
(2)  An actual or simulated act of sexual intercourse or masturbation; 
(3)  A lewd appearance in a state of partial or complete nudity; 
(4)  A lewd caress or indecent fondling of the body of another person; 
(5)  A lewd caress or indecent fondling of the sexual organs of any person, including oneself; 
(6)  Urination or defecation; or 
(7)  Appears wearing pants or skirts more than three inches below the top of the hips (crest of the ilium) exposing the skin or undergarments. 
(b)  When court appearance required, fines and penalties. 
(1)  Any person issued a citation or citations for violating any provision of subparagraphs (a)(1) through (a)(6) of this section 17-11 shall be summoned to, and shall appear in, the municipal court on the date for appearance as set forth on the citation. 
(2)  A citation issued for a violation of subparagraph (a)(7) of this section 17-11 shall be subject to a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) on the first offense and the violator shall not be required to appear in the municipal court, however, such violator must pay the fifty dollars ($50.00) fine within thirty (30) days of the date of receipt of the citation. The fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a first violation of subparagraph (a)(7) shall be payable at the office of the municipal court clerk at city hall. For each subsequent offense by a violator of subparagraph (a)(7), the violator shall be summoned to, and shall appear in, the municipal court on the date for appearance as set forth on the citation. 
(3)  The fine for violating any provision of subparagraphs (a)(1) through (a)(6) of this section 17-11 shall be as determined by the judge of the municipal court of the city subject to the provisions for monetary fines as set forth in section 4.13 of the City Charter and section 1-11 of the Code of Ordinances of the city. 
(4)  The fine for a second or subsequent violation of subparagraph (a)(7) of this section 17-11 shall be as determined by the judge of the municipal court of the city subject to the provisions for monetary fines as set forth in section 4.13 of the City Charter and section 1-11 of the Code of Ordinances of the city. 
(5)  Violators shall not be subject to arrest or imprisonment for violation of subparagraph (a)(7). 
(c)  Defenses. It is a defense under this section 17-11 if it is determined, after a hearing or trial, that the person was exercising rights protected by the federal or state constitution. Any defense under this subsection must be asserted prior to any hearing or trial in the matter. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, Pt. 1, 10-4-11) 
Sec. 17-12. - [Damage to property.] 
It shall be unlawful for any person to damage any real or personal property owned by the City of Stone Mountain. 
(Ord. No. 2015-04, Pt. I, 5-5-15) 
Secs. 17-13—17-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MINORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 06-13, Pt. I, adopted Sept. 5, 2006, amended the Code by repealing former Art. II, §§ 17-36—17-39, and adding a new Art. II. Former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1976, §§ 10-1007—10-1010; and Ord. of March 19, 1991. 

Sec. 17-36. - Responsibility of parents. 
It shall be unlawful for any parent, guardian, or other person having the custody of or control of any minor to permit, or by inefficient control, allow a violation of this ordinance by a minor in his or her custody. 
(Ord. No. 06-13, Pt. I, 9-5-06) 
Sec. 17-37. - Responsibility of proprietors. 
It shall be unlawful for the proprietor, manager or other person having charge or control of any public or other place to permit, allow or encourage any minor to violate this article in or around such place. 
(Ord. No. 06-13, Pt. I, 9-5-06) 
Sec. 17-38. - Curfew; persons age 16 years of age or younger. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any minor sixteen (16) years of age or younger to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, lanes, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any place in the city unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. on any day and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; provided, however, that on Fridays and Saturdays the effective hours are between 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and provided, that the provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)  When a minor is accompanied by his or her parent, guardian, or other adult person having lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(2)  When the minor is upon an emergency errand by his or her parent or guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(3)  When the minor is departing or returning home from a school or church activity; 
(4)  When the minor is departing to or returning from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above referenced places during the proscribed period; 
(5)  When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from activity involving the exercise of first amendment rights of speech, freedom of assembly, or free exercise of religion; 
(b)  Failure to comply with any of the requirements and provisions of this article shall constitute a violation and any parent or guardian, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or be imprisoned in the county jail for not more than thirty (30) days or any or all of these penalties, in the discretion of the municipal court judge. A fine and imprisonment not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and thirty (30) days may be ordered for violators at the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 06-13, pt. I, 9-5-06) 
Cross reference— Licenses and business regulations, ch. 12; parks and recreation, ch. 19; streets and sidewalks, ch. 25. 
Secs. 17-39—17-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ALARM SYSTEMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Police, ch. 21. 

Sec. 17-61. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm system means an assembly of equipment and devices designated and arranged to detect and signal an unauthorized intrusion into premises or to signal an attempted robbery on protected premises, and with respect to such signal public police are expected to respond. 
False alarm means the activation of a burglary and or robbery alarm by other than a forced entry or attempted forced entry to the premises and at a time when no burglary or robbery is being committed or attempted on the premises. 
Response means the dispatch of a police officer to the premises where an alarm system has been activated indicating a burglary and or robbery is presently in progress on those premises. 
(Ord. of 2-7-89) 
Sec. 17-62. - Penalties. 
Any person or business violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be summoned to the municipal court for each violation and noncompliance and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 2-7-89) 
Sec. 17-63. - Prohibitions. 
It is unlawful for anyone to activate any robbery or burglary alarm for the purpose of summoning police except in the event of an actual or attempted burglary or robbery, or for anyone notifying the police of an activated alarm and having knowledge that such activation was apparently caused by an electrical or other malfunction of the alarm system, or was apparently caused by maintenance or service to the alarm system, to fail at the same time to notify the police of such apparent malfunction or repair. 
(Ord. of 2-7-89) 
Sec. 17-64. - False alarm fees. 
For a police response to any false alarm, the municipal court shall fine and collect from the person or business having and/or maintaining a burglary and/or robbery alarm system on the premises owned or occupied by him fees as follows: 
(1)  For a first response to premises at which no other false alarm has occurred within a calendar year, a written warning and a copy of this article shall be given, but the person having or maintaining such burglary and or robbery alarm shall, within three (3) working days after notice to do so make a written report to the chief of police, or his appointed representative, and if applicable, on forms prescribed by him setting forth the cause of such false alarm, the corrective action taken, whether such alarm has been inspected by an authorized serviceman, and such other information as may require to determine the cause of such false alarm and corrective action necessary. 
(2)  For a second response to premises after a first response within a calendar year period, twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged, but a written report shall be required as for a first response and the chief of police or his appointed representative shall be authorized to inspect or cause to be inspected the alarm system at the owner's expense by a certified person and to prescribe necessary corrective action. 
(3)  For a third and a fourth response to premises after a second response within a calendar year, one hundred dollar ($100.00) fee shall be charged, but a written report shall be required as for a first response and the chief of police or his appointed representative shall be authorized to inspect or cause to be inspected the alarm system at such premises, prescribe necessary corrective action, and shall give notice to the person or business having or maintaining such alarm system of the conditions and requirements of this article, including the fee requirements for five (5) or more false alarm responses by the police within each calendar year. 
(4)  After a fourth response to premises within a calendar year, and for all succeeding responses within that calendar year, a fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) shall be charged, and if such false alarms are as a result of failure to take necessary corrective action prescribed by the chief of police, or his appointed representative, and may order the disconnection of such alarm system. It shall be unlawful to reconnect such alarm system until such corrective action is taken. No disconnection shall be ordered as to any premises required by law to have an alarm system in operation. 
(Ord. of 2-7-89) 
Sec. 17-65. - User fees. 
Any person or business which maintains an alarm system which has a direct connection to an alarm display panel located in the communications center of the department of public safety shall be charged a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) per month for such connection. 
(Ord. of 2-7-89) 
Sec. 17-66. - Requirements. 
The owner of each business, residence or structure equipped with an alarm system must provide the police department or their alarm company with a minimum of three (3) emergency phone numbers of persons who can be contacted in the case of an emergency or malfunction of the system. Listed persons must be able to enter the business, residence or structure and secure the system if a malfunction should occur or take appropriate action with the alarm company to secure the system within thirty (30) minutes of its reported failure. 
(Ord. of 8-7-90) 
Secs. 17-67—17-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REGISTRATION, SALE AND DISPOSITION OF FIREARMS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Inclusion of the provisions of §§ I—V of an ordinance adopted Sept. 4, 1990, as §§ 17-76—17-80 was at the discretion of the editor, the ordinance being nonamendatory of the Code. 

Sec. 17-76. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires, the terms shall have the meanings ascribed as follows: 
Dealer means any person regularly engaged in the business of selling firearms. 
Firearms means any pistol, revolver or derringer, by whatever name known, which is designed to expel a projectile or projectiles by the action of an explosive, and a firearm muffler or a firearm silencer, or any part or parts of such weapon. 
Identification means any driver's license, birth certificate, U.S. military identification card, baptismal or christening certificate, employee's identification card provided same shows age and home address of employee, and U.S. passport. 
Person includes an individual, partnership, association or corporation. 
(Ord. of 9-4-90(2), § I) 
Sec. 17-77. - Identification of purchaser. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any dealer in firearms or for any employee, servant or agent of such dealer to sell, transfer, deliver or dispose of, in any way, any firearms unless the person obtaining the firearm shall furnish identification to the dealer setting forth the person's name, present address and age. No dealer in firearms, nor any employee, servant or agent of such dealer, shall sell, transfer, deliver or dispose of in any way a pistol, revolver or short-barreled firearm the barrel of which is less than fifteen (15) inches in length, to any person within the city unless there shall first have been compliance with each of the provisions of this section. For the purpose of this section, a dealer in firearms shall include any person engaged in the business of operating a pawnshop, or other place where money is advanced on goods or other effects, or merchandise of any kind is taken in pawn. 
(b)  No dealer in firearms, or any employee, servant or agent of such dealer, shall sell, transfer, deliver or dispose of, in any way, a pistol, revolver or short-barreled firearm less than fifteen (15) inches in length unless the prospective purchaser shall have first obtained a certificate of approval from the chief of police and submitted such to the dealer. 
(c)  The applicant shall file with the police department an application furnished by the department stating the applicant's name, any and all names by which the applicant may have been previously been known, sex, race, age, height, color of hair, color of eyes, present address, any and all addresses for the applicant for the past five (5) years; whether the applicant has been convicted of any crime of violence within the past five (5) years; whether the applicant has been convicted of any felony related to firearms, sex, alcohol or drug offenses within the past five (5) years; whether the applicant has been found guilty of the violation of any law governing the use of firearms within the past five (5) years; whether the applicant is presently a fugutive from justice from any police jurisdiction within the United States; whether the applicant is presently suffering from any mental illness, whether the applicant has been treated for any mental illness within the past ten (10) years, and if so, the location of the hospital or mental institution providing such treatment; and whether the applicant presently has a valid permit issued to O.C.G.A. section 16-11-129, and, if so the date of issuance and the county of issuance of such permit. The application shall also provide the name and address of the dealer from whom the purchaser will purchase the firearm and the date such application is completed by the applicant. 
(d)  The applicant shall provide a full set of fingerprints as may be required by the police department; furthermore, the applicant shall authorize the department to conduct a background history of any criminal record which the applicant may have related to his qualifications to purchase a firearm pursuant to this section. The applicant shall further authorize the police department to obtain such hospital or mental institution records as may be required to determine the applicant's qualifications for purposes of this section. 
(e)  After receipt of the application, the chief of police or his designee shall conduct an investigation of the applicant, including a search of the applicant's fingerprint records, and hospital or mental institution records, if any. 
(f)  The applicant shall pay to the police department a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for processing of the application, and this fee shall be paid at the time the application is delivered to the police department. 
(Ord. of 9-4-90(2), § II; Ord. of 6-7-94(2), § II) 
Sec. 17-78. - Waiting period. 
No dealer in firearms, or any employee, servant or agent of such dealer, shall sell, transfer, deliver or dispose of, in any way, a pistol, revolver or short-barreled firearm less than fifteen (15) inches in length unless the prospective purchaser shall have first provided identification and registered with the dealer for purchase of the firearm fifteen (15) days prior to sale, transfer, or disposal of the firearm to the purchaser. 
This section shall not be construed to apply to noncartridge weapons. 
(Ord. of 9-4-90(2), § III) 
Sec. 17-79. - Conditions of sale. 
(a)  The chief of police or his designee shall disapprove the disposition if the chief or his designee shall determine that any of the following conditions apply to the applicant: 
(1)  Such applicant has been convicted of a crime of violence within the past five (5) years. For the purpose of this subsection a crime of violence shall mean murder, manslaughter, rape, mayhem, assault, aggravated assault, assault with intent to rape, assault with intent to murder, assault with intent to rob, simple assault, simple battery, aggravated battery, robbery, burglary, kidnapping, or the crime of attempting to commit any of the aforesaid crimes. 
(2)  The applicant has been convicted of any felony related to firearms, sex, alcohol or drug offenses within the past five (5) years. 
(3)  The applicant has been found guilty of the violation of any law governing the use of firearms within the past five (5) years. 
(4)  The applicant is presently a fugitive from justice from any police jurisdiction within the United States. 
(5)  The applicant is presently suffering from any mental illness. 
(6)  The applicant fails or refuses to complete the application or fails or refuses to complete any part of the application process. 
(7)  The applicant is under twenty-one (21) years of age at the time the application is submitted to the police department. 
(b)  The issuance of a pistol permit to the applicant under the provisions of O.C.G.A. section 16-11-129 shall be prima facie evidence of good cause for the approval of the application by the chief of police or his designee. 
(c)  In the event the application is approved and the applicant elects to obtain a firearm from a dealer other than the dealer whose name appears upon the application, the applicant shall notify the chief of police of the name and the address of the dealer; and the chief or his designee shall promptly notify the dealer, in writing, of the applicant's eligibility to obtain a firearm or firearms as provided herein. 
(d)  If at any time during the period for which the applicant retains his eligibility to obtain a firearm the chief of police or his designee shall learn or have brought to his attention in any manner any reasonable ground to believe the applicant is not entitled to retain his eligibility to obtain a firearm, the chief of police or his designee may revoke the applicant's eligibility and shall promptly notify the dealer whose name appears upon the application of such revocation. The chief of police or his designee shall further confiscate from the applicant any firearm obtained in contravention of the provisions of this section. 
(e)  In the event an applicant's eligibility is revoked, or in the event the applicant's application is disapproved, the chief of police or his designee shall promptly notify the applicant of such disapproval or revocation and shall further notify the applicant that the applicant shall have the right to appeal the disapproval or revocation to the governing authority. After a hearing, the governing authority shall thereupon report its findings and recommendations to the chief of police that their findings either affirmed or overruled his action. After receiving the findings of the governing authority, the chief of police or his designee shall take the appropriate action as required by this section. 
(Ord. of 9-4-90(2), § IV) 
Sec. 17-80. - Exemptions. 
(a)  This article shall not be construed to apply to toy pistols, toy revolvers or toy weapons of any kind, or to antique weapons which are used only for display. This article shall further not apply to casual sales between bona fide gun collectors; nor shall this article apply to any marshal; deputy marshal, sheriff, prison or jail warden, deputy prison or jail warden, correctional officer, policeman or other authorized law officers. No person regularly engaged in the manufacture, repair of sale of firearms shall be required to make application to obtain firearms as provided by this article. It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly provide false information on an application to obtain firearms as provided in this article. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and fined five hundred dollars ($500.00) or thirty (30) days in a common jail or both. 
(Ord. of 9-4-90(2), § V) 
Secs. 17-81—17-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LOITERING[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 02-8, Pts. I, II, adopted July 2, 2002, amended the Code with the addition of sections 17-81—17-83. In order to allow for the future expansion of article IV, the provisions of said ordinance have been designated article V, sections 17-101—17-103 at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 17-101. - Generally. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of loitering when the person is in a place at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. 
(b)  Among the circumstances, which may be considered in determining, whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify him or herself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impractical, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself or herself and explain his or her presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the foregoing procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. 
(Ord. No. 02-8, Pts. I, II, 7-2-02) 
Sec. 17-102. - Minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any parent, guardian or other person having the custody or control of any minor to permit, allow or encourage such minor to violate section 17-101. 
(Ord. No. 02-8, Pts. I, II, 7-2-02) 
Sec. 17-103. - Responsibility of proprietors, managers, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for the proprietor, manager or other person having charge or control of any public or other place to permit, allow or encourage any minor to violate section 17-101 in such place. 
(Ord. No. 02-8, Pts. I, II, 7-2-02) 
Chapter 18 - PARADE AND ASSEMBLY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-04, adopted September 6, 2011, amended the Code by repealing former ch. 18, §§ 18-1—18-7 and 18-36—18-45, and adding a new ch. 18. Former ch. 18 pertained to parades, demonstrations and picketing, and derived from the Code of 1976, §§ 6-2002, 6-2004—6-2010; an Ord. of June 7, 1988; and Ord. No. 2011-01, adopted February 1, 2011. 
Charter reference— Municipal powers, § 1.12. 
Cross reference— Animals, ch. 4; health and sanitation, ch. 11; licenses and business regulations, ch. 12; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 13; noise control, ch. 15; nuisances, ch. 16; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 17; parks and recreation, ch. 19; streets and sidewalks, ch. 25. 
State Law reference— Operation of motor vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Parade and Assembly Ordinance of the City of Stone Mountain." 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-2. - Definitions. 
Assembly means a group of two (2) or more persons who are together for a common cause or purpose, who stand, walk, congregate, or assemble upon any of the sidewalks, streets, or public property of the city, who evidence their cause by signs, slogans, common dress, solicitation of money, support, or membership, public speech, or the distribution of written materials. 
Assembly permit is a permit as required by this chapter to assemble within the city. 
Parade is any parade, march, ceremony, demonstration, show, exhibition, pageant, or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, sidewalk, park or other public place in the city. 
Parade permit is a permit as required by this chapter to conduct a parade within the city. 
Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-3. - Exceptions. 
This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions, provided the police department is notified of each procession's time and route; 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities; providing such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; or 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
ARTICLE II. - PARADES 

Sec. 18-4. - Permit and fee required. 
No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the office of the city manager and the appropriate fee has been paid. Fees for parades shall be that rate adopted by resolution of the city council and maintained by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-5. - Application. 
A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the office of the city manager on forms provided by the city. 
(1)  Filing period. An application for a parade permit shall be filed not less than ten (10) days or more than sixty (60) days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(2)  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct the parade; 
b.  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name of the organization, the address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of that organization; 
c.  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade leader and who will be responsible for its conduct; 
d.  The date when the parade is to be conducted; 
e.  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point; 
f.  The approximate number of persons who, and animals (no hoofed animals allowed) and vehicles which, will constitute the parade; the type of animals, and description of the vehicles; 
g.  The hours when the parade will start and terminate; 
h.  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed; 
i.  The location by streets of any assembly areas for the parade; 
j.  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any assembly area or areas; 
k.  The interval of space to be maintained between units of the parade; 
l.  If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf of or for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant for the permit shall file with the office of the city manager a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his or her behalf; 
m.  Any additional information which the city manager shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue. 
(3)  Late applications. The city manager, where good cause is shown therefore, shall have the authority to consider any application hereunder which is filed less than ten (10) days before the date the parade is proposed to be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-6. - Standards for issuance. 
The office of the city manager shall issue a permit as provided for hereunder when, from a consideration of the application and from any other information as may otherwise be obtained, he or she finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city; 
(3)  The conduct of the parade will not unreasonably interfere with the movement of emergency equipment en route to an emergency call; 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to the assembly areas; 
(5)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; 
(6)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route; and 
(7)  The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-7. - Notice of rejection. 
The office of the city manager shall act upon the application for a parade permit within seven (7) days after the filing thereof. If the city disapproves the application, then there shall be mailed to the applicant within seven (7) days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of the action, stating the reasons for the denial of the permit or communicate sooner if the date for the parade requires a quicker response. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-8. - Appeal procedure. 
Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade permit to the city council. The appeal shall be filed with the city within five days after the notice of the action by the city is mailed as set forth in section 18-7. The council shall act upon the appeal within five days after its receipt and may grant or deny a permit by a majority vote of the members present. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-9. - Alternative permit. 
The office of the city manager, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within five days after notice of the action, file a written notice of acceptance with the city. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-10. - Contents of permit. 
Each application for a parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time; 
(2)  Minimum speed; 
(3)  Maximum speed; 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade; 
(5)  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade; 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade route in miles or fractions thereof; 
(7)  Such other information as the city may require which is necessary to verify full compliance with all applicable provisions of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-11. - Duties of permittee. 
(a)  A permittee hereunder shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(b)  The parade leader or other person heading or leading the activity shall carry the parade permit upon his or her person during the conduct of the parade. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-12. - Public conduct during parades. 
(a)  Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
(b)  Driving through parades. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when the vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(c)  Parking on parade route. The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to the effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street not properly posted and in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-13. - Revocation of permit. 
The city manager shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued hereunder upon application of the standards for issuance as herein set forth under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-14. - Distribution of material during procession prohibited. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to distribute or cause to be distributed from any vehicle participating in a parade or procession or other public demonstration in the public streets or public highways within the city limits any item, either perishable or otherwise, to any bystander or onlooker. It is also unlawful for any owner or operator of any vehicle participating in a parade within the city limits to allow or permit any item, perishable or otherwise, to be distributed to any bystanders or onlookers from the said vehicle. 
(b)  The term "vehicle" shall include any device which moves on wheels whether under its own power or otherwise. 
(c)  This prohibition shall apply to gratuities and to items offered for sale. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
ARTICLE III. - ASSEMBLY 

Sec. 18-15. - Permit required. 
No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any assembly unless an assembly permit has been obtained from the office of the city manager. There shall be no fee for this permit. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-16. - Application. 
A person seeking issuance of an assembly permit shall file an application with the office of the city manager on forms provided by the city. 
(1)  Filing period. An application for an assembly permit shall be filed not less than ten (10) days nor more than thirty (30) days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the assembly. 
(2)  Contents. The application for an assembly permit shall set forth the following information: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct the assemblage; 
b.  If the assemblage is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name of the organization and address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of that organization; 
c.  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be responsible for its conduct; 
d.  The date when the assemblage is to be conducted; 
e.  The approximate number of persons who, and animals (no hoofed animals allowed) and vehicles which, will constitute the assemblage; the type of animals and description of the vehicles; 
f.  A statement as to whether the assemblage will occupy all or only a portion of the sidewalks, streets, or public property of the city; 
g.  The location by streets of any assembly areas for the assemblage; 
h.  The time at which the participants will begin to assemble at any assembly area or areas; 
i.  Such other information as the city may require which is necessary to verify full compliance with all applicable provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Late applications. The city manager, where good cause is shown therefore, shall have the authority to consider any application hereunder which is filed less than ten (10) days before the date the assemblage is proposed to be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-17. - Notice of rejection. 
The office of the city manager shall act upon the application for an assemblage permit within seven (7) days after the filing thereof. If the city disapproves the application, then there shall be mailed to the applicant within seven (7) days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of the action, stating the reasons for the denial of the permit or communicate sooner if the date for the assemblage requires a quicker response. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 18-18. - Appeal procedure. 
Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of an assemblage permit to the city council. The appeal shall be filed with the city within five (5) days after the notice of the action by the city is mailed as set forth in section 18-17. The council shall act upon the appeal within five (5) days after its receipt and may grant or deny a permit by a majority vote of the members present. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, 9-6-11) 
Chapter 19 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-03, adopted May 3, 2011, amended the Code by repealing former ch. 19, §§ 19-1—19-6, 19-10, 19-11 and 19-20, and adding a new ch. 19. Former ch. 19 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1976, §§ 4-4001—4-4004 and 4-4006; Ord. No. 96-9, adopted November 12, 1996; Ord. No. 97-6, adopted April 1, 1997; and Ord. No. 99-7, adopted August 3, 1999. 
Charter reference— Municipal powers, § 1.12. 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, ch. 10; health and sanitation, ch. 11; parking at recreation facilities, § 13-60; noise control, ch. 15; curfew for minors, § 17-38 et seq.; parade and assembly, ch. 18. 
State Law reference— Parks, historic areas, memorials, etc., and recreation, O.C.G.A. § 12-3-1 et seq.; municipal recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - PARKS AND RECREATION FACILITY RULES 

Sec. 19-1. - Hours. 
Unless otherwise provided by this section, parks and recreation facilities shall open at 7:00 a.m. and shall close at sunset, except that parks containing lighting for night use shall close at 10:00 p.m. Only those areas of parks and recreation facilities which are illuminated and in use at night shall be interpreted as being open. All other portions of such facilities not illuminated are considered to be closed. Applicable closing signs shall be conspicuously posted at all parks and recreation facilities and any deviation from the information contained on the signs must be approved in writing by the city. 
A park or a portion of a park that has been designated by the mayor and council to be used as a "dog park" shall be open beginning November 1 and continuing through March 31 on Mondays through Fridays from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.; on Saturdays from 9:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. and on Sundays and holidays from 10:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. The "dog park" shall be open beginning April 1 and continuing through October 31 on Mondays through Fridays from 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m.; on Saturdays from 9:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. and on Sundays and holidays from 10:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. Holidays are to be defined as Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve, Christmas, New Years and Easter. 
When the "dog park" is open until 8:00 p.m. the hours from 7:00 p.m. until 8:00 p.m. shall be designated as "quiet time" and owners shall not allow their dogs to bark excessively during this time. Owners who do not comply shall be instructed by the volunteer dog owner on duty to remove their dog from the dog park. The volunteer dog owner on duty shall be responsible for contacting emergency 911 when owners do not remove their dogs from the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11; Ord. No. 2011-11, 11-1-11) 
Sec. 19-1.1. - Dog park rules and regulations. 
The following rules and regulations are applicable to all designated dog parks within the corporate limits of the city and their purpose is to provide for orderly use of city dog parks to ensure public health, safety and the general welfare to the residents of the city. 
(1)  Park users, dog owners and dog handlers assume all risk related to use of the dog park. 
(2)  Each dog owner or dog handler is legally and financially responsible for the actions of their dog or dogs in the dog park. 
(3)  Dogs must at all times be under the control of a responsible adult and obedient to the owner's or handler's commands. 
(4)  No aggressive dogs are allowed in the dog park. "Aggressive dog" means any animal that constitutes a physical threat to persons or other animals of such severity as to cause physical injury. 
(5)  Dogs that bark excessively or dogs that become aggressive must be leashed and removed from the dog park immediately. 
(6)  Children younger than twelve (12) years of age are not allowed inside the off-leash dog exercise area of the dog park unless accompanied by an adult. Children under six (6) years of age are prohibited in the dog park. 
(7)  Dogs under six (6) months of age, un-neutered male dogs and female dogs in heat shall not be permitted in the dog park. 
(8)  Dogs must be legally licensed, have current vaccinations and shall wear a visible license tag. 
(9)  Choke, prong, pinch and spike dog collars must be removed from the dog once inside the fenced area of the dog park. 
(10)  The dog owner or dog handler must carry a leash or lead at all times while in the dog park. 
(11)  Dogs must never be left unattended. 
(12)  Animal waste must be removed immediately and deposited in suitable containers. 
(13)  Dog owners and dog handlers must stop dogs from digging and must fill any hole created by their dog(s). 
(14)  There is a limit of three (3) dogs per visit per dog owner or dog handler. 
(15)  No food, drinks or dog chews are allowed within the fenced area of the dog park. 
(16)  No littering is allowed in the dog park. 
(17)  Climbing on or over the fencing in the dog park is not permitted. 
(18)  The city public works department shall have the authority to close access to the dog park for the purpose of maintenance, weather related occurrences and for special events. 
(Ord. No. 2011-14, Pt. I, 4-3-12) 
Sec. 19-2. - Using parks for golf practice, putting greens, driving ranges. 
No person shall use any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreation purposes as a field for golf practice, putting green or driving range. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-3. - Motor vehicles in parks. 
(a)  A motorized vehicle means a self-propelled, wheeled conveyance that does not run on rails. A motorized vehicle shall not include a wheelchair used by a person with disabilities as an auxiliary aid. A wheelchair means a device designed solely for use by a mobility-impaired person for locomotion that is suitable for use in an indoor pedestrian area. 
(b)  No person shall operate a motorized vehicle of any kind or nature in or on any city park, bicycle path, or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. This section does not prohibit persons with disabilities from using a wheelchair as an auxiliary aid in or on any city park, bicycle path, or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. 
(c)  This section does not prohibit the use of motorized vehicles for maintenance purposes or motorized vehicles using marked roads, driveways or parking areas. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-4. - Permit required for organized games, assemblages or gatherings, erection of booths or sale of articles. 
(a)  The city clerk shall oversee scheduling of all city owned parks and public places for organized games, assemblages or gatherings. 
(b)  No person shall be allowed to erect any booth or stand or to sell any article within the limits of any of the public parks without approval from the city council. 
(c)  Application. All persons desiring to reserve a park shall make application to the city clerk. Applications shall be submitted no less than seventy two (72) hours prior to the reservation date(s) and shall be made by the person or persons responsible for the reservation. All applications must be approved by the city clerk and chief of police and must be accompanied by the required fees. 
(d)  Limited reservations. Reservations shall be limited to one (1) reservation per month per person or group per park for no more than three (3) consecutive days. For the purpose of this chapter, "group" is defined as a collection of individuals who have regular contact and frequent interaction, mutual influence, common feeling of camaraderie, and who work together to achieve a common set of goals; this includes individual teams or team members of a league or other affiliation. Reservations shall not be accepted earlier than six (6) months in advance of the date for city residents or three (3) months in advance of the date for all non-residents. 
(e)  Refusal or revocation of permit. The city reserves the right to refuse or revoke permits. Such a determination shall be based on health, safety and welfare of the public and protection of city property. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11; Ord. No. 2011-07, 8-2-11) 
Sec. 19-5. - Alcoholic beverages. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or possess any alcoholic beverages on public property or within the vicinity of any parks or recreation facilities of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-6. - Drug free zones defined. 
City parks, or any portion thereof, are hereby declared a drug free zone. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-7. - Animals in parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who harbors, possesses or is in charge of a domestic restrained or unrestrained animal (such as dogs, cats, etc.) to bring said animal onto any city owned athletic field, playground, and/or outdoor basketball court. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride, graze or walk a horse or other type hoofed animal within municipal parks. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person who possesses, harbors, or is in charge of any animal not to immediately remove excrement deposited by the animal while in the municipal park. Animal excrement shall be removed from the park and disposed of in a sanitary means. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to an animal aiding the handicapped (e.g., guide dog) or to an animal when in police or rescue activities. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-8. - Special prohibitions. 
(a)  Paint. It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to possess paint, in any form, in or on any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreation purposes. 
(b)  Glass containers. No person shall possess a glass container in or on any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreation purposes. 
(c)  Bicycles on athletic fields. No person shall ride or walk a bicycle or other non-motorized vehicle in or on any athletic field owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. This section does not prohibit persons with disabilities from using a wheelchair as an auxiliary aid on such fields. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to affix any bill, sign or notice on any tree, building or fixture in any of the parks of the city. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute handbills or dodgers or scatter or place any paper, books, refuse or trash of any kind in or about any of the public parks of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-9. - Closing of athletic fields. 
The city may close to the public athletic fields for maintenance purposes. Such closed fields shall be posted and it shall be unlawful for any person to enter a closed field. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-10. - Public address systems and outdoor entertainment. 
No public address systems, loud speakers, amplifying devices or outdoor entertainment shall be used in city parks without first making application to the city police department. Applications shall be submitted to the police department no less than seventy-two (72) hours prior to the event and shall be made by the person or persons responsible for the event. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-11. - Firearms; firecrackers; air guns; slingshots; explosives; destructive substances; dangerous missiles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to handle or discharge any firearm, firecracker, air gun, slingshot or other explosive, noisy or destructive article or substance, or throw any stone or other missile in, about or across any of the parks belonging to or in the care of the city. This section shall not prohibit law enforcement officers from using firearms or other weapons in the performance of their duty. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-12. - Fires safety regulations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to build or maintain a fire in any park or other facility owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes except for fires contained in permanently mounted grills or personal grills. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11; Ord. No. 2016-07, Pt. I, 2-2-16) 
Sec. 19-13. - Vegetation—damage or removal. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dig up, cut, damage or remove any tree, tree limb, shrubbery, flowers, rock, mulch or other vegetation/natural fixture located in any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to personnel employed or engaged by the county to maintain city parks and recreational areas or an authorized group of volunteers involved in a city-approved project for the enhancement of a park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-14. - Artifact or treasure hunting. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to search any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes for historic artifacts or for the purpose of locating lost or abandoned personal property of another, unless such person specifically is authorized by the owner of that personal property to make such search on the owner's behalf. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any historic artifacts or lost or abandoned personal property of another from any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes unless such person specifically is authorized by the owner of that personal property to recover such personal property on the owner's behalf. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dig in or otherwise disturb the ground in a park or other area owned by the city for recreational purposes, except as permitted by the city. 
(d)  This section does not prohibit a person from visually searching for and reclaiming his/her own lost property in any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes, either by himself/herself or by someone specifically authorized by the owner of the lost personal property to act on his/her behalf. 
(e)  The prohibitions of this section shall not apply to law enforcement personnel engaged in the lawful execution of their duties or to persons employed or engaged by the city when performing their duties in any park or other area owned or operated by the city for recreational purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-15. - Commercial activity. 
Unless approved by the city council it shall be unlawful for any person in any city park to: 
(1)  Sell or offer for sale any merchandise; 
(2)  Operate or attempt to operate a concession; or 
(3)  Engage in any commercial or charitable activity in a city park. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-16. - Native wildlife. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to remove or disturb any living or dead native creatures in city parks, including mammals, birds, fish, amphibians, and reptiles, or the parts or progeny thereof, such as nests, eggs, or antlers. 
(b)  Fishing activities in city park lakes or streams shall be allowed from the shore of a body of water 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Sec. 19-17. - Pollution or disturbance of springs, creeks, or ponds. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to pollute or disturb any spring, branch, pond or other water within the confines of any of the parks belonging to the city by wading by persons or animals, throwing sticks, stones, refuse or trash in or by washing the person or objects in such waters. 
(Ord. No. 2011-03, 5-3-11) 
Chapter 20 - PERSONNEL POLICY AND PROCEDURES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-05, adopted July 6, 2010, amended the Code by repealing former ch. 20, §§ 20-1, 20-11—20-14, 20-21—20-28, 20-31—20-35, 20-41—20-48, 20-51—20-54, 20-61—20-63, 20-71—20-76, 20-81—20-83, 20-91—20-93, 20-101—20-106, 20-111—20-113, 20-121—20-126, 20-131, 20-141—20-145, 20-151, 20-152, 20-161, 20-171, 20-181—20-188, and 20-191—20-200; and adding a new ch. 20. Former ch. 20 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from ordinances of July 3, 1990; December 3, 1991; April 7, 1992; July 7, 1992; December 1, 1992; May 3, 1994; Ord. No. 96-4, adopted April 9, 1996; Ord. No. 96-10, adopted December 3, 1996; Ord. No. 96-11, adopted December 3, 1996; Ord. No. 01-4, adopted April 3, 2001; Ord. No. 02-7, adopted May 7, 2002; Ord. No. 04-16, adopted December 7, 2004; Ord. No. 06-11, adopted May 2, 2006; Ord. No. 08-02, adopted March 4, 2008; Ord. No. 08-06, adopted June 3, 2008; and Ord. No. 2010-01, adopted January 5, 2010. 
Charter reference— Rules and regulations, § 4.15. 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 

ARTICLE I. - ESTABLISHMENT 

Sec. 20-1. - Establishment. 
A system of personnel administration is hereby established for the city. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-2—20-10. - Reserved 
ARTICLE II. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-11. - Purpose. 
(a)  The general purpose of this chapter is to establish a system of human resource administration that meets the program needs of the people of the city and provide fair and equitable working conditions for city employees that will encourage career employment. This chapter shall provide a means to recruit, select, develop and maintain a responsive work force and shall include policies and procedures for employee recruitment, hiring and advancement, training and career development, job classification, salary administration, fringe benefits, disciplinary action and grievance handling. All appointments and promotions shall be based upon an objective evaluation of merit and fitness to perform the work required. 
(b)  Discrimination against any person in recruitment, selection, appointment, training, advancement, retention or other personnel action in the city because of political opinion or affiliation, religious belief, race, color, sex, national origin, age or physical disability, if such age or physical disability is not related to employment performance, shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-12. - Personnel administration generally. 
(a)  Mayor and council. The mayor and council shall receive and act upon recommendations of the city manager for amendments, additions to, and changes in the rules and regulations. The establishment of all personnel policies are subject to the approval of the mayor and council and shall not become effective until such approval is given. However, once policies are approved, the responsibility for implementation and operation will be delegated to the city manager. 
(b)  Personnel director. The city manager shall serve as the personnel director for the city. The personnel director shall be responsible for implementing, carrying out and enforcing the approved rules and regulations of the personnel system. He is the executive head of the personnel department and shall direct all of its activities and appoint its employees. He may delegate such duties and responsibilities as he deems appropriate to personnel department staff members or other city department heads, but he still remains accountable for complying with all rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-13. - Personnel policies. 
All employees serve at will and may be removed from office at any time unless otherwise provided by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-14. - Positions covered. 
All employees of the city. For the purpose of this chapter the following personnel are not considered employees of the city and are not subject to these provisions: 
(1)  All officials elected by popular vote; 
(2)  Members of appointed boards and commissions; 
(3)  Individuals employed by the city council in their professional capacities to conduct temporary or special inquiries, investigations and examinations on behalf of the mayor and council; 
(4)  The city attorney and any employee of his office; 
(5)  Municipal court judges; and 
(6)  City manager. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10; Ord. No. 2013-04, pt. I, 3-5-13) 
Sec. 20-15. - Departmental regulations. 
Each city department head is authorized to prepare such individual departmental personnel rules and regulations as may be necessary in the accomplishment of the operation of the department. Such departmental rules and regulations may not be in conflict with any provision of this chapter and must be approved in writing by the city manager. The city manager will review all proposed departmental regulations to insure that they are consistent with the rules and regulations of the city and advise the appropriate department head in writing of his findings. The city manager shall discuss with the mayor and council, with counsel by the city attorney, any proposed regulations about which he has questions. Departmental regulations which have been approved by the city manager shall be displayed in a public place in the department at least five (5) days prior to their effective date. Each employee shall be furnished a copy of all departmental regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-16—20-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CLASSIFICATION PLAN 

Sec. 20-21. - Purpose. 
The purpose of the classification plan is to group all positions into categories or classes on the basis of a systematic plan for recognizing similarities and differences in job duties and responsibilities. The classification plan provides a complete inventory of all classified positions in the city service and an accurate description and specifications for each class of employment. The plan standardizes titles, each of which is indicative of a broad range of duties and responsibilities and has the same meaning throughout the classified service. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-22. - Composition of plan. 
The classification plan shall consist of: 
(1)  A grouping, in classes, of positions which are approximately equal in difficulty and responsibility, which call for the same general qualifications, and which can be equitably compensated within the same range of pay under similar working conditions; 
(2)  Class titles, descriptive of the work of the classification which identify the job; and 
(3)  Written specifications for each class of positions. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-23. - Use of classification titles. 
Classification titles are to be used in all personnel, accounting, budget, and financial records of the city. No person will be appointed to or employed in a position covered by this article under a title not included in the classification plan. Other job titles may be used as a working title in the course of departmental routine to indicate authority, status in the organization, or administrative rank, but must be considered working titles only and not official classification designations. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-24. - Use of classification specification. 
The classification specifications are descriptive and not restrictive. They are intended to be interpreted in their entirety and in relation to others in the classification plan. Particular phrases or examples are not to be isolated and treated as full definition of the class. Specifications are deemed to be descriptive and explanatory of the kind of work performed and not necessarily inclusive of all duties performed. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-25. - Administration of the plan. 
The city manager is charged with the responsibility for the maintenance of the classification plan so that it will reflect the duties performed by each employee in the classified service and the class to which each position is allocated. It is his duty to see that the classification plan is initiated by assigning each position currently existing to an appropriate classification. It is also the duty of the city manager to examine the nature of new positions as they are created, and to allocate them to an existing class or to recommend the creation of new classifications in conformity with this chapter. The city manager shall also be charged with the responsibility of recommending to the mayor and council changes in the classification plan as are made necessary by changes in the duties and responsibilities of existing positions and periodically reviewing the entire classification plan and recommending to the mayor and council appropriate changes in the classification plan. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-26. - Allocation of classification titles to position. 
In initially implementing the classification plan, the city manager shall use the classification specifications approved by the mayor and city council and accompanying this article. Whenever a new position is established, or duties of an old position changed, department heads shall submit in writing a comprehensive job description describing in detail the duties of such a position. The city manager shall, thereupon, investigate the actual or suggested duties and assign the position an appropriate classification. The city manager shall, prior to notifying the respective department head and employee of the classification assigned insure that funds are available to fund the designated classification. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-27. - Reclassification request. 
Any employee who considers his or her position improperly classified shall first submit a request through channels to his or her department head who shall review such request as to its justification. If the department head finds that there is merit to the request, he shall immediately transmit a recommendation to the city manager. If the department head finds that the request is not justified, he shall advise the employee of that decision but shall also advise the employee that the request may be sent to the city manager with the notation that the department head does not consider the request justified. The city manager shall take appropriate action in connection with all reclassification requests received. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-28. - Status of employees upon reclassification. 
Upon reclassification of a position from one (1) class to another class of the same level, a lower level, or to a higher level, the method of filling the position shall be determined in accordance with the rules regarding transfers, demotions, or promotions, as may be appropriate. However, when the incumbent of a position, through diligent and intelligent application to his work, develops his position by assumption of more difficult additional responsibilities and duties so that it warrants a higher classification, the department head may recommend to the city manager that the employee be given status in such higher classification without posting the position as a job vacancy. The city manager may approve or disapprove such recommendations. An employee who is reclassified to a position having a lower pay range shall not be reduced in salary unless the employee's present salary is above the maximum salary at the pay grade of the class to which he is reclassified, in which case the employee's salary shall be reduced to the maximum salary for the new class. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-29, 20-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COMPENSATION PLAN 

Sec. 20-31. - Purpose. 
The purpose of the compensation plan is to establish and maintain a pay system for city employees which is equitable and uniform, which provides comparable pay for comparable work, and which will allow the city to attract and retain employees and to compete in the job market with other private and public employers in the area. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-32. - Composition of plan. 
The compensation plan includes the basic salary schedule as adopted by the mayor and council and subsequent amendments thereto, and the schedule of salary ranges consisting of minimum and maximum rates of pay and intermediate steps for all classes of positions included in the classification plan. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-33. - Maintenance of compensation plan. 
The compensation plan is intended to provide fair compensation for all classes in the classification plan with regard to range of pay for other classes, general rates of pay for similar employment in private establishments and other public jurisdictions in the area, cost of living data, the financial condition of the city, and other factors. In maintaining this plan, the city manager will from time to time make comparative studies of all factors affecting the level of salary ranges and will recommend to the personnel committee such changes in salary ranges as appear to be pertinent. After reviewing the recommendations of the city manager, the personnel committee of the council shall make recommendations to the mayor and full council for changes in the compensation plan as the committee deems appropriate. Upon approval by the mayor and council, the compensation plan may be changed and the salaries of all city employees affected will be appropriately adjusted to reflect the salary changes. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-34. - Use of salary ranges. 
Salary ranges are intended to furnish administrative flexibility in recognizing individual differences among positions allocated to the same class, in providing employee incentive, and in rewarding employees for meritorious service. The following general provisions shall apply to salaries established in connection with appropriate salary ranges: 
(1)  New appointments. The entrance salary for all new employees shall be at the minimum level (step 1) of the class to which the new employee is appointed, except in those cases where unusual circumstances appear to warrant appointment of an employee at a higher rate. Any department head desiring to appoint an applicant at a salary above the minimum shall submit in writing an explanation enumerating the reasons why the applicant should be appointed above the minimum. With appropriate justification, the city manager may approve an appointment above the minimum entrance level. However, in no case may an employee be appointed at a beginning salary in excess of step 3 of the compensation plan. A city employee who terminates his or her employment with the city also terminates all length of service and is not automatically entitled to be rehired at a rate higher than the entrance level for the position. 
(2)  Salary upon promotion, demotion, or transfer. 
a.  Promotion. An employee who is advanced to a classification calling for a higher pay range than the previous classification shall have his salary raised to the minimum rate of pay for the new classification or two (2) pay steps, whichever is greater. One (1) additional step may be granted upon completion of the probation period. The department head must submit the appropriate personnel action forms for this increase to be given. An employee who has been promoted may not participate in annual performance increases until twelve (12) months have passed since the date of promotion. 
b.  Demotion. An employee who is demoted shall be reduced in salary to the pay grade of the position to which he is demoted and shall be placed in the same step order within the new grade as he occupied in the former position. However, in no case will an employee who is demoted after receiving a promotion in the previous year be reduced in pay below the pay he was receiving at the time of the promotion. 
c.  Transfer. "Transfer" shall mean lateral reassignment of an employee from one position class to another position class with the same salary range. When an employee is transferred, the employee shall be paid at the same step rate he received prior to his transfer. Completion of the probationary period and scheduled merit or cost of living increases shall not be affected by an employee transfer. 
(3)  Salary range adjustments. In accordance with recommendations made by the city manager or because of other considerations, the mayor and council may adjust the total wage structure of the pay plan. 
(4)  Performance based increases. All employees of the city shall be periodically (not less than once each year) appraised regarding their individual job performance. 
a.  Annual appraisal. The performance of all employees, supervisory and nonsupervisory, shall be appraised at least annually between September 1 and October 31. 
b.  Probationary review. The performance of all employees, supervisory and nonsupervisory, shall, upon their entering a new position, be appraised during the second, fourth and fifth months of the probationary period. 
c.  Probationary period. Six (6) months is the designated probationary period for all jobs. When the employee's performance proves to be marginal, the department head may request extension of the probationary period by an additional six-month interval. Such request will be supported by appropriate performance appraisal documents and submitted to the city manager for review. Only one (1) such six-month extension of the probationary period shall be granted. Employees whose performance fails to reach an acceptable level of performance shall be returned to their former level/position, if available, reassigned (if a job vacancy exists that they are qualified for), or dismissed under the provisions of the merit system. 
d.  Supervisory appraisals. Supervisors shall be appraised by their department head on three (3) key factors: setting and tracking goals; managing subordinates (including affirmative action); and achieving results (including resource management.) 
e.  Nonsupervisor appraisals. Nonsupervisory personnel shall be appraised by their immediate supervisors on forms issued by the city. The supervisors shall carefully evaluate all their employees' performance for the past year using job related criteria, position descriptions, on the-job performance, related personnel records, and standards of judgment that reflect a fair assessment of each employee's performance. 
Upon completion of the appraisal, supervisors shall meet with each employee to discuss the appraisal, employee's career aspirations, areas of needed improvement and training or self-help opportunities that the employee might pursue. 
The employee shall sign the appraisal form acknowledging an understanding of the evaluation, but not necessarily agreement. 
Note: The grievance process may not be used if the employee disagrees with the appraisal. 
The appraising supervisor shall forward a copy of the signed form to his/her immediate supervisor for review, discussion and signature. 
The appraisal shall be sent to the personnel department for inclusion in the employee's file. 
The performance appraisals shall be used by the department heads to determine if an increase is warranted. No pay increase will be approved unless required performance appraisal has been completed and forwarded to the personnel department. 
(5)  Maximum rate exceptions. The maximum rate in the range for any classification may not be exceeded with the exception that an employee's salary range at the time of adoption of this chapter shall not be reduced if it exceeds the maximum rate of the range to which his/her position is allocated under the new classification system. Such an employee's salary shall be frozen until such time as the employee is promoted or the salary range for his/her position is increased to exceed the employee's present salary. There is no provision in this plan for longevity increases to carry an employee beyond the maximum rate for the classification assigned to the employee's position. 
(6)  Pay for part-time workers. Whenever an employee works for a period of less than the regular established number of hours per week for the position held, the amount of pay shall be proportioned to the time actually employed. The payment of a separate salary from two (2) or more departments for duties performed by a single employee is permissible if the total salary received is not in excess of the maximum rate of pay for the employee's classification. Employees may be hired on an irregular or temporary basis with approval of the City Manager. Such employees will be paid on an hourly basis for the time actually worked. 
(7)  Probationary increases; new employees. Newly hired employees may be granted a one-step increase following successful completion of probation. Such increases are not automatic and must be requested by the department head, supported with appropriate performance appraisal documents and approved by the city manager. Such increases will be granted effective with the next pay period following receipt of request and performance appraisal documents. No increases will be retroactive. Newly hired employees shall not be eligible for participation in annual performance increases until twelve (12) months or more following the date of expiration of their probationary period. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-35. - Extra remuneration. 
(a)  Overtime. The normal workday and work period shall be established for each department independently in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act by the department head with the approval of the city manager. The workday and work period established may vary from department to department because of different work requirements. Payment for all hours established as the normal work period for a particular department shall be considered regular pay and shall be paid as straight time. Compensation for hours worked beyond the prescribed normal work-period hours shall be considered as overtime hours. Compensation for overtime hours shall be paid at the rate of one and one-half (1½) times the normal hourly pay rate. 
(1)  The city manager shall define supervisory and nonsupervisory employee categories, including categories exempt and non-exempt from the overtime provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act. 
(2)  Records to be maintained and submitted to personnel for overtime pay shall be as prescribed by the city manager. 
(3)  Extra remuneration. Employees may be given compensatory time in lieu of overtime pay provided there is an agreement or an understanding between the employee and the supervisor prior to performance of the overtime. Employees may be given compensatory time at a rate of one and one-half (1½) hours for each hour worked beyond their regularly scheduled work applicable under the Fair Labor Standards Act. Employees must use all compensatory time accrued within ninety (90) days after the end of the calendar year in which such compensatory time was earned. However, when work exigencies preclude the use of properly requested and approved leave to take compensatory time, such compensatory leave time may, upon the request of the department head and approval of the city council, be taken in the following calendar year. Employees may accrue a maximum of forty (40) hours of compensatory time per calendar year. Employees' compensatory time is authorized for ordered work or to work hours performed by employees which are in excess of eighty-five (85) hours per fourteen-day cycle for police personnel and forty (40) hours per seven-day cycle for civilian personnel. 
(b)  Uniform allowance. For job categories where employees are required to wear a prescribed type of clothing or uniform in connection with their employment, the mayor and council may establish uniform allowances which will be paid to employees in those classifications under a prescribed uniform allowance plan, or may provide that the city provide and pay for necessary uniforms. 
(c)  Court compensation for police officers. Police officers required to attend court within the county at times when they would have been otherwise in an off-duty status shall receive a flat fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per diem. Police officers required to attend courts outside the county while in an off-duty status will not receive the flat fee compensation, but will be permitted to retain the witness fees and mileage payable by those courts. If in on-duty status, the officer is required to turn the witness fees over to the clerk of the council promptly, but may retain the mileage payments if the officer used his/her privately owned vehicle.
