This compensation plan will be used in lieu of the overtime provisions of this plan, and police officers will not be entitled to overtime payment for court attendance while in an off-duty status, unless time required in court attendance would result in higher overtime pay than the flat fee allowance provided herein. In such case, the officer would be paid the higher rate, but in no case shall be receive both. 
(d)  Reimbursement for expenses for official travel. All city employees required to travel in connection with their official authorized duties will be compensated for travel expenses in accordance with the prescribed travel expense compensation policies of the city. These policies should be made available in written form to any employee who may be requested to travel in connection with city employment. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-36—20-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RECRUITMENT AND EMPLOYMENT 

Sec. 20-41. - Eligibility for employment. 
Individuals shall be recruited for employment with the City from a geographic area as wide as is necessary to obtain a sufficient number of well qualified candidates for various positions. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-42. - Equal opportunity statement. 
Selection for city positions will be made without regard to race, color, religion, sex, national origin, political affiliation, marital status, non-disqualifying physical or mental handicap, age, membership, or non membership in an employee organization, personal favoritism or other non-merit factors. Discrimination in the employment of any person who is an applicant for a position covered by this chapter is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-43. - Notification of available positions. 
The city shall prepare recruiting notices to publicize vacancies and to obtain candidates for vacant positions. All vacancies shall be posted at city hall. In addition, various public media shall be used to bring notices of vacancies to as many qualified persons as possible. Job vacancy notices will be posted for all vacancies in all departments of the city. Media advertising of vacancies may not be required of all vacancies, but shall be utilized as deemed necessary to reach a sufficient number of qualified persons. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-44. - Method of making application. 
Each applicant for a position within the city shall make application on a standard application form available at the city hall. Applications for employment shall be accepted only when a vacancy exists. Each candidate will be requested to designate the type of position or positions for which he/she is making [an] application. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-45. - Evaluation of applicant. 
The city manager shall establish whatever reference and investigation requirements shall be deemed necessary to determine the reputation, competence, honesty, stability, dependability and other necessary data on each applicant and promotional candidate for each position. For positions within the police department or other designated positions, such investigation will include at a minimum fingerprinting, physiological testing and a check of criminal conviction records. Applicants for positions designated as physically demanding may be required to undergo a physical examination at the city's expense prior to employment. All applicants for all jobs are required to undergo drug and alcohol testing at the city's expense prior to employment. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-46. - Examination program and procedures. 
The city manager may initiate and install a suitable examination program for any class or classes of employment. Examination programs may be conducted in cooperation with other governmental agencies if deemed appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-47. - Disqualification of applicant. 
The city manager shall remove from consideration the application of any applicant who: 
(1)  Does not possess the minimum qualifications for the position for which the application is made; 
(2)  By reference check evidences unsatisfactory employment or personal conduct to a degree so as to demonstrate unsuitability for employment; 
(3)  Has made any false statements or practiced deception in his application; 
(4)  Is found to be physically or mentally unqualified for the position for which the application is made; 
(5)  Does not reply to a mail inquiry within ten (10) calendar days or does not return a telephone inquiry within two (2) calendar days; 
(6)  Fails to accept employment or to report to duty within the time prescribed in an employment offer; or 
(7)  Has been employed previously by the city and has been removed for cause or did not resign in good standing, and is not recommended for re-employment by the head of the department in which the applicant was previously employed. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-48, 20-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - APPOINTMENT 

Sec. 20-51. - Types of appointment. 
The following types of appointment may be made under the provisions of this chapter in conformity with the rules established: 
(1)  Orientation period: Full-time and part-time employees are considered to be in an orientation period during their first six (6) months of employment. This period of time is for the employee to become familiar with the job duties and work requirements and for the supervisor to evaluate the employee's suitability for the job. At the end of this period, the employee will be evaluated and if satisfactory will be considered a regular employee. Temporary or contract employees who have worked with the City for five (5) months or more prior to becoming a regular employee will not go through an orientation period, will not be eligible for the six-month review and will be reviewed at the same time as other regular employees. 
(2)  Regular, full-time employees: Employees of the city who are not temporary or hired on a contract basis and who regularly work at least forty (40) hours per workweek are considered regular, full-time employees. The regular employee is subject to all rules and regulations and receives all benefits and rights as provided by the City Code, personnel ordinances, resolutions and rules and regulations. 
(3)  Regular, part-time employees: Employees of the city who are not temporary or hired on a contract basis and who regularly work fewer than forty (40) hours per workweek are considered regular, part-time employees. Part-time regular employees are not eligible for employee benefits unless specifically noted. The part-time regular employee is subject to all rules and regulations as provided by the City Code, personnel ordinances, resolutions and rules and regulations. 
(4)  Temporary employees: Individuals who work with the city pursuant to an agreement with an employment agency and who are employees of the agency and not the city are temporary employees. Individuals hired by the city for a specific period of time or until the completion of a particular project may also be temporary employees. Temporary employees are not eligible for employee benefits unless specifically noted. Temporary appointments may not be made for a period to exceed six (6) months, and employees in this status have no guaranteed employment continuation privileges under this plan. 
(5)  Non-funded appointment: An employee in this category is one appointed to work for the city in a position funded entirely or in part from a source other than city funds such as federal or state grant contracts. Such an employee is subject to all rules and regulations and is entitled to all benefits of this plan, except as limited by the conditions of the grant under which the position is funded. An employee in this category has no guarantee of employment continuation under this plan beyond the expiration of the grant, and will be informed in writing at the time of employment of this limitation. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-52. - Probationary status. 
(a)  Purpose. The probationary or working test period is an integral part of an employee examination process. It shall be utilized to observe closely the employee's work, to secure the most effective adjustment of the new, promoted, or regular employee to his position, and the rejection of any employee whose performance does not meet required work standards. 
(b)  Duration. The probationary period shall be six (6) months. However, if an extension of the probationary period is requested by a department head, at least thirty (30) days before expiration of the original probationary period, such an extension may be granted by the personnel director or city manager for a period of an additional six (6) months beyond the end of the normal probationary period. Any employee who is continued in probationary status beyond the original six (6) months' period shall be notified in writing of this continuation by the personnel director or city manager. 
(c)  Evaluation. Periodically during the probationary period at times prescribed by the personnel director, the department head or other designated supervisory person shall prepare a written evaluation of the probationary employee's performance and his willingness and ability to perform his duties satisfactorily. During the probationary period, the employee's supervisor will be responsible for counseling with the employee when he is not performing satisfactorily and is not meeting probationary test requirements. 
(d)  Dismissal. The department head, with concurrence from the city manager, may remove any employee on probationary status who is unable or unwilling to perform the duties of the position satisfactorily or whose habits and dependability do not merit his continuance in the employment of the city. Such an employee may be removed without prior notice and without the right of appeal. The department head will advise the employee, in writing, of such removal and shall immediately report such removal to the personnel director, stating his reasons. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-53. - Method of filling vacancies. 
Vacancies shall be filled by reemployment, promotional appointment, original appointment, transfer or demotion. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-54—20-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - CHANGE OF EMPLOYMENT STATUS 

Sec. 20-61. - Promotion. 
(a)  Promotion policy. Vacancies in positions above the lowest rank in any employment category may be filled by the promotion of employees of the city, but non-city employees may also be considered. The personnel director shall, in each case, post vacancy notices as prescribed in section 20-43 for all categories of employment above entrance level positions in-house for five (5) working days prior to advertising. This procedure will allow any interested employee who desires to be considered for promotion to be given adequate consideration. 
(b)  Application for promotion. Any regular employee who desires to be considered for promotion shall submit his request for consideration to be promoted to a specific position to the department head. 
(c)  Basis of awarding promotion. When any vacancy is to be filled from a promotion list, the selection of the employee to be promoted will be made by the department head after consultation with the city manager. If the city manager deems it necessary, he may interview the candidate for promotion for the purpose of evaluating the candidate's qualifications. The city manager, in coordination with respective department heads, may establish appropriate tests and examination procedures to be used by the city manager as a guide in evaluating the qualifications of employees under consideration. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-62. - Transfer. 
(a)  Definition of transfer. A transfer is the movement of an employee from one (1) position to another position in the same classification or to a position in another classification having the same pay range. 
(b)  Initiation of transfer requests. Transfers may be initiated in the following ways: 
(1)  An employee may request a transfer by submitting a written request for transfer to another position through his department head to the personnel director. As vacancies occur in other departments to which he would be eligible to transfer, his name will be submitted to the department head for consideration. 
(2)  An employee may be transferred without his consent upon the written recommendation of the department head or department heads concerned, with the approval of the personnel director. Employees may be transferred in this manner without the right of appeal since there would be no change in pay or other employment status, and the city must reserve the right to utilize employees in positions to meet operational needs. 
(c)  Status of transferred employee. The transfer of an employee from one position to another position should not change the status (probation or regular) which the employee has at the time of his transfer nor shall he suffer loss of any of the benefits and privileges afforded regular employees. 
(d)  Rights of transferred employee. A regular employee who was selected for transfer at his request may be permitted to transfer back to the former position or a comparable position if the employee is unable to perform the duties and responsibilities of the position to which transferred at an acceptable level of competence as determined by the department head. If no vacancy exists to which the employee may be returned, every effort shall be made to place the employee in another position for which he may be qualified. If an acceptable position cannot be found, the employee may be separated. Employees who have not completed their probationary period prior to transfer may be terminated during the probationary period just as any other probationary employee without the right of appeal. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-63. - Demotion. 
(a)  Definition. A demotion is the movement of an employee to a classification having a lower pay range than the pay range of his previous classification. A demotion can result from the reclassification of the employee's present position or the movement of the employee to a new position. 
(b)  Reasons for demotion. The following are reasons for demotion: 
(1)  When an employee does not perform the duties and responsibilities of his position at an acceptable level of competence as determined by his department head; 
(2)  When an employee is insubordinate or uncooperative or acts in a manner to lower discipline or morale within the city service or when he acts in a manner deemed not in the best interest of the city service, such employee may be demoted as a form of disciplinary action; 
(3)  When an employee voluntarily requests such demotion; 
(4)  When an employee would otherwise be laid off because his position is being abolished due to lack of work or lack of funds, or because it has been reclassified to a higher classification for which the incumbent is not qualified; or 
(5)  When an employee becomes physically incapacitated and is unable to perform the duties of the position. 
(c)  Demotion recommendation. When a department head determines that a demotion is necessary, appropriate, and in the best interest of the city, he may recommend to the personnel director that an employee be demoted. The recommendation shall be in writing and shall contain the reasons why it is necessary for the department head to recommend demotion and why demotion is being recommended rather than an alternative personnel action. The personnel director, with the approval of the city manager, will initiate demotion procedures if deemed appropriate. 
(d)  Notification of demotion. The personnel director shall notify a department head when a demotion recommendation has been approved, and it will be the responsibility of the department head to notify the employee of the demotion in writing, stating the reason(s) for the demotion, the effective date, and the employee's right of appeal from such demotion under article X. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-64—20-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - ATTENDANCE AND LEAVE 

Sec. 20-71. - Hours of work. 
The work week and the hours of work shall be uniform with occupational groups and in accordance with the needs of the city and the reasonable needs of the public. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-72. - Attendance. 
Each department head shall be responsible for the attendance of all persons within his department and shall keep attendance records on forms provided by the personnel office. Leave shall be authorized in units of days, half-days or quarter-days only. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-73. - Holidays. 
(a)  Official paid and unpaid holidays for full-time employees of the city are established by resolution of the mayor and city council. 
(b)  Holidays which occur during annual or sick leave shall not be charged against annual or sick leave. 
(c)  All full time employees will be paid for a normal work day for each paid holiday established by resolution of the mayor and council. Department heads are required to schedule paid leave for full time employees who are required to work on paid holidays within thirty (30) days of the paid holiday. Department heads are required to schedule unpaid leave for full time employees who are required to work on unpaid holidays within thirty (30) days of the unpaid holiday. Full time employees required to work on paid or unpaid holidays will be compensated at the normal rate of pay. No paid holiday leave accrues during leave without pay, disability leave, military leave, or absence while on worker's compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10; Ord. 2013-01, pt. I, 1-8-13) 
Sec. 20-74. - Annual (vacation) leave. 
(a)  Annual leave is a fringe benefit. Employees are encouraged to use their vacation time. 
(b)  Eligibility. All full-time employees in the personnel system shall be entitled to accrue annual leave. 
(c)  Rate of accrual. Regular full-time employees accrue leave for a month provided that their employment date is on or before the tenth of that month. Employees under part-time, provisional, temporary or emergency appointments shall not be eligible for annual leave. 
Annual leave is accrued per the following schedule for persons employed under a full-time appointment: 

 
(d)  Request for leave. A request for leave shall be submitted to the employee's immediate supervisor. Leave may be taken only after approval by the appropriate department head so that the department can function without hiring additional help. 
(e)  Stipulations governing annual leave. 
(1)  Unused annual leave not to exceed thirty (30) days may be carried into the next calendar year. At the end of December of each year, the city will authorize payment to any employee who has accumulated annual leave in excess of the maximum accrual amount. Such payment shall be at the employee's normal hourly rate of pay and shall only be made to the employee's deferred compensation plan. 
(2)  An employee separated from the city service shall be paid for all unused annual leave up to a maximum of thirty (30) days. 
(3)  Annual leave may be used in one-hour increments. 
(4)  Any employee who separates from the city and is reemployed at a later date shall be treated as a new employee in regard to rate of accrual for annual leave. 
(5)  An employee must be in pay status for a minimum of fifteen (15) working days in order to earn leave for that calendar month. For purposes of this section, the term "in pay status" shall mean that the employee is working his or her regular work schedule or is on approved leave or approved holiday. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-75. - Sick leave. 
(a)  As used in this section, "sick leave" shall mean paid leave that may be granted to an eligible employee who through sickness, injury or disability becomes incapacitated to a degree that makes it impossible for him or her to perform the duties of his or her position, or who is quarantined by a physician because of exposure to a contagious disease. An employee may use accrued sick leave in the case of: 
(1)  Personal illness, injury or disability. 
(2)  Medical, dental or eye examination for which arrangements cannot be made outside of regular working hours. 
(3)  When the employee is required to care for sick or injured spouse, child, including foster child, or other close relative (mother, father, grandmother, grandfather, brother, sister, or a relative living with the employee). 
(4)  Quarantine restriction. 
(5)  Pregnancy. 
(b)  The employee shall report any illness prior to his or her scheduled work time, if possible. If not, he shall see that the illness is reported within thirty (30) minutes of the scheduled beginning work-time. 
(c)  Sick leave is a benefit granted to employees to assure that employees are not penalized for illness, injury or disability, and is to be used strictly in accordance with the above reasons. Any use of sick leave for vacation or other use is prohibited, and shall subject the abusing employee to disciplinary action including termination and forfeiture of pay for such time used in violation of these policies. 
(1)  Eligibility. All regular full-time employees are entitled to earn sick leave. 
(2)  Rate of leave accrual. Regular full-time employees accrue sick leave at the rate of one (1) day per month (twelve (12) sick days per year.) Regular full-time employees accrue sick leave for that month provided, their employment date is on or before the tenth of the month. Employees under part-time, provisional, temporary or emergency appointments shall not be eligible for sick leave. An employee must be in pay status for a minimum of fifteen (15) working days in order to earn leave for that calendar month. For purposes of this section, the term "in pay status" shall mean that the employee is working his or her regular work schedule or is on approved leave or approved holiday. 
(3)  Certification by physician. A medical certificate signed by a licensed physician may be required by the city manager to substantiate a request for sick leave for the following reasons: 
a.  Any period of absence consisting of three (3) or more consecutive working days. 
b.  To support a request for sick leave during a period when the employee is on vacation. 
c.  If absence from duty recurs frequently or habitually, the employee shall be notified that a certificate will be required at the next absence. 
(4)  Stipulations governing sick leave. 
a.  Sick leave may not be accumulated in excess of one hundred twenty (120) working days. 
b.  No sick leave in excess of that accumulated may be granted. For an extended illness, an employee may use his annual leave or the employee may use sick leave donated to him by another employee. When all sick leave is exhausted, an employee may be granted leave without pay for the duration of the illness. 
c.  An employee who is separated from the city shall forfeit all unused sick leave; no employee shall be paid for unused sick leave. 
d.  Sick leave may be used in one (1) hour increments, but no less than one (1) hour. 
e.  Each eligible employee shall be responsible for reporting to the personnel officer, at the end of each pay period, any sick leave used by him or her. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-76. - Other types of leave. 
(a)  Military leave. The city complies with all relevant state and federal laws concerning military leave obligations. Employees who have reserve obligations or who are called to active duty should inform their supervisor as early as possible. Any employee, other than a temporary employee, who is a member of any force of the organized militia or of any reserve force or reserve component of the armed forces of the United States will be allowed leave of absence for ordered military duty without loss of pay for a period not exceeding a total of eighteen (18) calendar days in any one (1) federal fiscal year. This means that if there is a difference between military pay for ordered military duty and the employee's salary, the city will pay the difference between regular compensation and the amount received as base pay from military service. If the governor declares an emergency and orders an employee to active military duty as a member of the National Guard, that employee shall be paid for up to thirty (30) days in one (1) federal fiscal year. All other military leave is unpaid. An employee may elect to take annual leave instead of time off without pay for unpaid military leave. Time during which an employee is on ordered military duty shall not constitute an interruption of continuous employment. No employee shall be subjected directly or indirectly to any loss or diminution of time, service, increment, vacation, holiday privileges, or any other right or privilege by reason of such absence or be prejudiced with reference to continuance in employment, reemployment, reinstatement, transfer, or promotion by reason of such absence. 
(b)  Workers compensation. An employee who is temporarily disabled because of injury or illness sustained directly in the performance of his work may be covered by the provisions of the state workers compensation act. An employee who receives workers compensation payments may elect to use annual and/or sick leave to pay the difference between workers compensation payment and their regular pay but in no case shall the total (workers compensation and annual/sick leave pay) received by the employee exceed their regular pay. 
(c)  Temporary disabilities (not covered by workers compensation.) A temporarily disabled employee shall be allowed to exhaust his sick and vacation leave accumulations. Further extensions of leave (either with or without pay) must be specifically authorized by the city manager after recommendation by the department head. 
(d)  Leave of absence without pay. The city manager, upon recommendation of the department head, may grant a permanent employee leave of absence without pay for a period not to exceed six (6) months. 
(1)  Leave without pay shall be granted only when it will not adversely affect the interest of the city government. 
(2)  Failure to return to work at expiration of approved leave is regarded as absence without leave and constitutes abandonment of the job. 
(3)  An employee will be required to pay the city to continue health and dental insurance while in leave without pay status. 
(4)  An employee who wishes to return before the leave of absence period has expired shall give his department head at least one (1) week's notice. If such written notice is submitted, the employee must be permitted to return to work. 
(5)  No sick leave, annual leave, nor credit toward merit increases will be earned by an employee in leave without pay status. 
(6)  An employee shall return from leave without pay to the same step of his previous salary grade and in the same or equivalent class where employed when leave began. 
(e)  Funeral leave. Funeral leave of up to three (3) working days or twenty-four (24) hours will be granted with pay for an employee absent from duty as a result of death in the immediate family. For purposes of this section, "immediate family" shall mean spouse, child, father, mother, grandparents, grandchildren, father-in-law, mother-in-law, brother, sister or any other relative who is domiciled in the employee's household. 
Funeral leave of up to one (1) working day will be granted with pay for an employee absent from duty as a result of death of any other relative not stated above. 
Funeral leave of up to two (2) hours will be granted with pay for employees absent from duty to attend funerals of people other than relatives. 
Employees are expected to take no more funeral leave than is necessary. However, if more leave is required than is provided for in the above; annual leave, if approved, may be used. 
(f)  Civil leave. An employee who is summoned for jury duty or subpoenaed as a witness in a court case shall be granted leave with pay for the length of such service. The employee shall notify his department head of such required service as soon as summoned or subpoenaed, and shall exhibit such document as proof. The employee shall report for service only as required, and shall return to work as soon as he or she is dismissed from service in court. Failure to abide by these requirements shall subject the employee to disciplinary action, and to forfeiture of pay for all time other than that actually required in court. 
(g)  Severe weather and other leave. Under certain adverse weather conditions and other circumstances recognized by the city, the city manager may grant paid or unpaid time off. These instances occur on a case by case basis and the city reserves the right to authorize time off on a discretionary basis. In questionable instances of adverse or inclement weather, employees should first call into the office to see if a phone message regarding closing has been posted and secondly be guided by those same attendance instructions affecting DeKalb County employees as may be published by local radio or television stations. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-77—20-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - SEPARATION. 

Sec. 20-81. - Methods of separation. 
An employee may be separated from the service of the city government by any of the eight (8) methods as described below: 
(1)  Resignation. An employee may resign by submitting a written resignation to the department head stating the reasons for resigning and the effective date. Notice of resignation should be provided to the department as far in advance as possible, but a minimum of two (2) weeks' notice is required for an employee to resign in good standing unless the department head agrees to accept a shorter notice because of extenuating circumstances. 
(2)  Abandonment of position. Failure to report to work without valid reason and without authorized leave for three (3) consecutive work days shall be cause for separating an employee from the payroll and reporting him as having abandoned the position. The same rule shall apply when an employee fails to return to work within three (3) days of the expiration of authorized leave. Employees who abandon their positions may be denied future employment with the city. 
(3)  Lay-offs. Adverse economic conditions, business and operational needs, and the best interests of the city and its citizens may on occasion necessitate that the city reduce job positions. When the city determines that lay-offs are necessary, the lay-offs will generally be conducted in accordance with the procedures contained in this policy, unless exceptional circumstances exist. The department head will make a recommendation to the city manager as to the positions within the department which the department head recommends reducing. The city manager will have the final authority in choosing which positions to reduce. The department head and city manager may consider the following criteria in determining which positions to reduce: (1) demonstrated current and past performance, including corrective/disciplinary actions; (2) transferability of skills to other positions and promotional potential; (3) length of service; and (4) other business and operational factors underlying the need to reduce job positions. This is not an exhaustive or inflexible list of factors, and the department head and city manager should consider the overall best interests of the city and the department in choosing which positions to reduce and which employees to retain. 
(4)  Disability. An employee may be separated for disability when he cannot perform the required duties because of a physical or mental impairment. Action may be initiated by the employee, his legal representative or the city personnel director with the approval of the city manager; but in all cases, it must be supported by medical evidence acceptable to the city manager. In disability or potential disability cases, the city may require the employee to have an examination at its expense and performed by a physician of its choice. When a disability does occur and impairs the effectiveness of an employee or others, the following action shall be taken: 
a.  If the disability is correctable, the employee shall be allowed a specified time, as determined by the city manager and the department head based upon the physician's recommendation, to have it corrected. If he fails to take steps to have the disability corrected within this specified time, he shall be subject to disciplinary action or lay-off. 
b.  If, in the opinion of the examining physician, the disability cannot be corrected, the city manager shall attempt to place the employee in another position which he can perform satisfactorily. If that cannot be accomplished successfully, the department head shall take steps to separate the employee from the City service through retirement or lay-off. 
(5)  Loss of job requirements. An employee unable to perform the job adequately because of loss of required licensing, certification or other qualifying factor shall be separated by lay-off. If the employee is re-certified, re-licensed or satisfactorily achieves the qualifying factor and a vacant position is available, he may be considered for re-employment. 
(6)  Death. Separation shall be effective as of the date of death of any employee covered by this chapter. All compensation due including payment for time worked, payment for any accrued annual leave and payment for any outstanding compensatory time shall be paid to the designated beneficiary or beneficiaries of the estate of the employee except for such sums which by law must be paid to the surviving spouse. 
(7)  Retirement. When an employee meets the conditions set forth in the retirement plan regulations of the city, he may elect to retire and receive all benefits under the retirement plan. 
(8)  Dismissal. Any employee whose work is unsatisfactory over a period of time may be dismissed by his department head. Dismissal normally takes place only after an employee has received an oral warning, a follow-up written reprimand which has been discussed with the employee, and where suspension has been shown to be ineffective. However, dismissal need not be preceded by prior disciplinary action. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10; Ord. No. 2012-06, pt. I, 11-6-12) 
Sec. 20-82. - Rights of employees. 
An employee separated for any reason is entitled to receive notice, in writing, of his separation and the reasons therefore. All separated employees shall receive payment for any accrued annual leave to which they may be entitled. Any employee who is separated in good standing will be entitled to be considered for future employment with the city. Any employee whose separation was not in good standing shall not be considered for re-employment in the city service. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-83—20-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - DISCIPLINARY ACTION 

Sec. 20-91. - Types of disciplinary action. 
Whenever an employee's performance, attitude, work habits or personal conduct at any time falls below a desirable level, the supervisor shall inform the employee promptly and specifically of such lapses and give counsel and assistance in an attempt to correct deficiencies. If improvement is not evident after a reasonable period of time, more severe disciplinary action may be required. In some instances, a specific incident may justify severe disciplinary action. Except in extreme cases, disciplinary action in the form of dismissal will not be taken until reprimand(s) and/or suspensions have been used. A department head, subject to the appeal rights of the employee shall have the following alternatives for disciplinary action: 
(1)  Oral reprimand. An employee may be called in for private conference regarding unacceptable behavioral patterns or work performance standards. An oral reprimand shall be documented and placed in the employee's personnel file. If there is no recurrence of the violation which resulted in the oral reprimand within twelve (12) months of the issuance of the oral reprimand, the documentation shall be removed from the employee's personnel file. 
(2)  Written reprimand. A written reprimand may be given to an employee when: 
a.  An oral warning has not resulted in the desired improvement, or 
b.  When initial action required greater discipline than an oral warning. 
A copy of the written reprimand shall be filed in the employee's personnel file. If there is no recurrence of the violation which resulted in the written reprimand within twenty-four (24) months of the issuance of the written reprimand, the documentation shall be removed from the employee's personnel file. 
(3)  Suspension. A department head may suspend without pay an employee in his department for up to five (5) days. A written statement specifically setting forth the reasons for the suspension shall be furnished to the employee. Copies shall be filed with the city manager and in the employee's personnel file. With prior approval of the city manager, the length of the suspension may be extended to not more than ten (10) days. Documentation regarding suspension shall become a part of the permanent personnel record of the employee and shall not be removed from the file. 
(4)  Demotion or reduction in salary. A department head may reduce the salary of an employee within a pay grade assignment or demote the employee for cause to a position in a lower graded class. A written statement of the reasons for such action shall be furnished to the employee. Copies shall be filed with the city manager and in the employee's personnel file where they shall become a part of the permanent record. 
(5)  Dismissal. A department head may dismiss an employee as outlined in section 20-81(8). The employee shall be furnished notice of the dismissal in writing, stating the reasons and his right to answer the charge. The employee may also be notified that he has no re-employment rights in the city service as provided in this article. Copies shall be filed with the city manager and in the employee's personnel file, where they shall become a part of the permanent record. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-92. - Standards of conduct. 
The city endeavors to employ responsible individuals and believes that the vast majority of employees are responsible citizens who understand and respect the rights and property of their fellow employees and that of the city. However, when large groups work together, reasonable rules are necessary for the orderly conduct of the operation. To this end, the city has in effect and will establish from time to time such reasonable rules as it considers necessary to ensure the orderly and efficient conduct of its business, to assure the safety of its employees and property, and to comply with applicable laws. During working hours employees are expected to comply with rules established by the city. Failure to do so may result in discharge or other appropriate disciplinary measures. 
The violation of any of the following rules will result in disciplinary action ranging from an oral correction to discharge: 
(1)  Habitual tardiness or absenteeism. 
(2)  Failure to report immediately to the supervisor any job-related accident or injury or unsafe working condition. 
(3)  Failure to report an off-the-job accident or injury which may affect the performance of your job. 
(4)  Smoking in restricted areas. 
(5)  Gambling during work or on city property. 
(6)  Working on personal business or projects on city time. 
(7)  Creating or contributing to unsanitary or disorderly housekeeping conditions. 
(8)  Failing to notify the city promptly when you will be absent from work or late to work. 
(9)  Soliciting employees while either the person being solicited or the person doing the soliciting is on work time. This applies to selling of any type; solicitation of memberships, pledges, or subscriptions; circulating petitions, or collecting money. 
(10)  Conduct which endangers you or another employee. 
(11)  Unauthorized use of city tools, equipment, telephones or other city property. 
(12)  Failure to use safety equipment required by the city or to comply with safety rules. 
(13)  Distribution of literature or printed material of any kind in the work area or during work time or posting or removing notices, signs or other written materials. 
(14)  Remaining on or coming onto city work premises during off-duty hours for purposes other than to work without advance approval (employees may report early and/or leave late due to transportation arrangements). 
(15)  Sleeping, loafing on the job, engaging in horseplay, throwing anything that may harm another, playing jokes or otherwise distracting or startling others, acting in a disorderly manner or being away from your work station unnecessarily. 
(16)  Refusal or failure to carry out instructions fully or to perform work assignments as required by supervisory personnel. 
(17)  Gross negligence or abuse resulting in the damage or destruction of tools, machinery, equipment, products, materials, or other property belonging to the city or to others. 
(18)  Removing city property from your work site without written authorization. 
(19)  Operating or tampering with city equipment which you have not been authorized to use or repair. 
(20)  Restricting work production, encouraging or persuading others to restrict work production or supporting an interruption of work. 
The first violation of any of the following may result in immediate discharge. 
(1)  Obtaining materials or tools through fraudulent orders or misrepresentations. 
(2)  Bringing and/or consuming alcohol, drugs or narcotics at work or working on the job under the influence of alcohol, drugs or narcotics. From time to time there may be city-sponsored events where alcoholic beverages may be served and employees are expected to conduct themselves in an orderly manner. 
(3)  Carrying explosives or unauthorized weapons on a work site. 
(4)  Deliberate action causing damage or destruction or waste of tools, machinery, equipment, product, materials or other property belonging to the city, a city official or to a fellow worker. 
(5)  Giving false information in making application for employment or pursuant to any city inquiry or investigation. 
(6)  Immoral or indecent conduct on a work site, including abusive or threatening language to any employee or the making of false or malicious statements or defaming another employee, city official or the city. 
(7)  Fighting or attempting bodily injury to others on a work site except in clear cases of self-defense. 
(8)  Stealing or hiding any property of other employees, persons, city officials, cities or the city. 
(9)  Failure to return to work from an authorized leave-of-absence. 
(10)  Being absent three (3) consecutive working days without calling in. 
(11)  Divulging confidential information to an unauthorized person or making any disclosure of confidential information regarding the city to any person, agency, publication, radio or television station without authorization from the city (see confidential information). 
(12)  Abusive conduct toward a fellow employee, city official or member of the public. 
Please remember these are only examples of violations which may result in disciplinary action or immediate discharge. Other situations of a similar nature may arise and these too may result in various degrees of discipline or discharge. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-93. - Appeal rights. 
Any employee who has been suspended without pay, demoted, reduced in pay or dismissed shall have the right to appeal such action as provided in article X of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-94—20-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - GRIEVANCES AND APPEALS 

Sec. 20-101. - Policy. 
Grievances should be adjusted informally if possible. Both supervisors and employees are expected to make every effort to resolve problems as they arise. However, there may be grievances which will be resolved only after formal appeal and review. No employee shall be disciplined or discriminated against in any way because of use of the grievance procedure. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-102. - Definition. 
A grievance is a wrong, real or imagined, considered by an employee as grounds for complaint. A formal grievance is a written complaint made by an employee concerning the interpretation of these rules and regulations, departmental work rules or disciplinary action affecting his employment with the city, including, but not limited to, separation from employment as provided in this chapter. It is desirable for all grievances to be settled informally and both supervisors and employees are expected to make every effort to resolve problems as they arise. However, there will be grievances which will be resolved only after a formal appeal and review. Accordingly, this article provides for both informal and formal grievance procedures. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-103. - Informal employee complaint. 
An employee who has a problem or complaint should first try to get it settled through discussion with his immediate supervisor without undue delay. If, after this discussion, the employee does not believe the problem has been satisfactorily resolved, he shall have the right to carry the problem through channels to the department head if the department head is not the employee's immediate supervisor. Every effort should be made to find an acceptable solution by informal means at the lowest possible level of supervision. However, after carrying the problem or complaint to the head of the department in which he is employed, if the employee is not in agreement with the decision reached by discussion, he shall then have the right to file a formal grievance in writing within five (5) working days after receiving the informal decision of the department head. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-104. - Steps in formal grievance procedure. 
An employee who has been unable to resolve a grievance or complaint to his satisfaction using an informal procedure may initiate formal grievance action in the following manner: 
(1)  Departmental hearing. An employee may submit a formal grievance or complaint in writing to the department head within ten (10) working days after the occurrence of the act or actions in which the grievance is based, or within five (5) working days after informal discussion has failed to satisfactorily resolve the complaint or grievance. A copy of such appeal shall be transmitted by the department head to the city manager to be used as a basis for any future appeal which may be submitted in accordance with the provisions of this plan. Such written appeal shall state the nature of the grievance, the supervisor or supervisors through whom the employee has attempted to resolve the grievance on an informal basis and the relief that the employee desires in making the appeal. A department head shall respond with a formal written decision to any employee grievance within five (5) working days after he personally receives the grievance appeal. 
(2)  City manager hearing. An employee who has filed a formal grievance appeal at the department level and who is dissatisfied with the decision at the departmental level may file a formal written appeal through the department to the city manager within five (5) working days after receipt of the departmental decision. The same written format used for the departmental appeal will be used in filing an appeal with the city manager. The city manager will be required to render a decision, in writing, to the employee within five (5) working days after he personally receives the employee's appeal. 
(3)  Personnel hearing officer. The mayor and city council hereby establish the personnel hearing officer (PHO). The PHO shall be an attorney who is a member in good standing of the state bar and is appointed by the mayor and city council after consultation with the city manager and city attorney regarding the PHO qualifications and duties. Employees who are subject to dismissal from employment pursuant to section 20-81(8); loss of income through disciplinary suspension; demotion; or who claim illegal discrimination or harassment in violation of federal law, state law, or this Code shall have the right to due process through the managerial chain of command up to and including an administrative review in the form of an appeal hearing before the appointed PHO. The PHO is interested in the fair treatment of employees, with proper recognition and concern for the efficient and effective operation that local government services provide to the citizens of the city. The PHO shall exhibit mature reasoning, prudent stewardship of public funds, evidence of good judgment, and impartial and nonpolitical performance of these duties. 
a.  Appeals to the personnel hearing officer. An employee who is not satisfied with the decision rendered by the city manager in connection with a formal grievance appeal may, within five (5) working days from receipt of such decision, file a formal written appeal with the PHO. The PHO has final authority within city government to hear grievance cases brought by employees who exercise their right to appeal adverse actions which are described in section 20-104(3). The PHO shall determine if management's decision is supported by the evidence, lies within the lawful discretion of management, and is consistent with City past practice and recognized general management procedure, based on facts, circumstances, and the employee's previous record. 
b.  Criteria for review. In reviewing appeals cases, the PHO shall be guided by the following criteria. It shall be the burden of the appellant to establish by a preponderance of the evidence that the adverse action or practice in question: 
1.  Does not substantially comply with sound management principles and is not consistent with the policies and procedures of city. 
2.  That the factual basis upon which the adverse action was taken is not true and correct or was substantially inaccurate in all relevant and material aspects. 
3.  That the adverse action is not reasonable, given the severity of the offense. 
4.  That an illegal discrimination or harassment practice exists in the work place which affects the appellant and which has not been properly addressed or terminated by the management. 
c.  Appeal hearings. In reviewing the action taken by management, the PHO shall confirm or rescind the adverse action in question. The PHO is not authorized to substitute an alternative form of discipline. Decisions made by management may be reversed if the PHO finds the appellant has met his or her burden of proving any of the criteria for review set out in the previous subsection. The PHO may provide management with supplementary observations, comments, and recommendations regarding alternative levels of discipline for consideration by management. The PHO shall adopt procedures for the conduct of appeal hearings. Meetings, admissibility of information, and rules of evidence may be informal as compared to formal judicial proceedings. The PHO's decision shall be the final decision of the city. 
d.  Types of cases. Issues heard by the PHO will include suspensions, demotions, dismissal from employment pursuant to section 20-81(8) and claims of illegal discrimination or harassment. The PHO shall not hear appeals involving temporary records such as corrective interview documentation, performance evaluations, and notices of reprimands or similar documentation temporarily held in the employee's personnel file. 
e.  Appointment of personnel hearing officer. The mayor shall make a nomination to the city council for appointment of one (1) attorney as the primary PHO and one (1) or more alternate hearing officers shall be similarly appointed in case the primary PHO is not available when needed to conduct a hearing. The PHO shall be appointed by a majority vote of the entire city council and may be removed by majority vote of the entire city council. The initial appointment shall be for a two-year term and shall be subject to replacement or reappointment at the end of the term. 
f.  Conduct of hearings. The PHO shall conduct public hearings and render decisions to confirm or overturn management decisions adversely affecting an appellant. All testimony before the PHO shall be rendered under oath or affirmation, by oral testimony or depositions and with the right of cross-examination. All decisions made by the PHO shall be entered into the minutes of the PHO meeting, which shall be open to inspection by the public during regular office hours. 
g.  Amendments to policies and procedures. The PHO shall be authorized to make recommendations to the city manager as to amendments, additions to, and changes in the city employment policy and procedures. 
h.  Appeal hearings and record keeping. The PHO shall hold appeal hearings as soon as necessary when properly petitioned by a City personnel system employee who has a qualified reason for requesting a hearing. All such hearings shall be open to the public. The city manager shall set the date, time and place of the meeting, providing proper notification to the affected parties. The time and place of each appeal hearing; names of the persons present; and all official acts of the PHO shall be recorded in the minutes. An agenda, including all items to be presented to the PHO, shall be prepared by the city manager prior to each appeal hearing. The minutes shall be transcribed and presented for approval or amendment by the PHO. Upon approval, these minutes shall be open to inspection by the public, employees and department heads. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-105. - Administrative procedures. 
In connection with the grievance procedure steps set forth hereinabove, the following administrative procedures and regulations shall apply: 
(1)  The time limit specified in all grievance steps may be extended to a definite day by mutual agreement of the employee and the reviewer or reviewing body concerned for good and valid cause. Unless extended by mutual agreement, the time limits specified shall be met by all parties at each step. Failure by the employee to meet any time limit specified shall constitute a withdrawal of the grievance. Failure by the city or the department head involved in the action, the city manager, or the PHO to respond within the time limit specified shall constitute agreement with the employee, and shall result in a finding for the employee. 
(2)  The employee will be entitled to be assisted by or represented by any person of his choosing at the employee's own cost in preparing and presenting his appeal at any level of the grievance procedure. The city may also be represented by its appointed city attorney or other person of its choosing. 
(3)  The employee shall be assured freedom from reprisal for using the grievance procedure. A regular employee may use the grievance procedure as an appeal route for any act or action affecting his employment unless such appeal is specifically prohibited under the rules and regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-106. - Status of grieving employee. 
The employment status of any employee utilizing formal grievance procedure will not be changed as a result of the initiation of grievance procedures. A disciplinary action which has been taken against an employee in the form of dismissal or suspension will not be changed as a result of an employee's initiating a grievance appeal nor shall it be changed while the appeal is in process. At the completion of the grievance process action taken which changes an employee's status may be initiated in accordance with the decision rendered in connection with the grievance appeal. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-107—20-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - WORK SCHEDULES, ATTENDANCE, HOURS OF WORK 

Sec. 20-111. - Work schedules. 
Work schedules for all employees shall be determined on a departmental basis by the department head. The schedule showing the beginning and ending times for the specified shifts in departments where shift scheduling is required must be posted in a conspicuous location in the departments. The normal workday for departments not involved in shift scheduling is 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., with a one-hour period for lunch away from the work station, and with two (2) breaks daily, not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes each, as scheduled by the department head. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-112. - Work week. 
Employees on a regular full-time appointment shall work forty (40) hours per week except in those departments where city regulations have established a different work week for the department. All work weeks shall be in compliance with the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-113. - Attendance of employees. 
Regular and punctual attendance at work shall be required of all city employees. All departments will establish and post specific regulations concerning notification to the department by employees when they will be unable to be in attendance at the designated time and place. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-114—20-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - CONDUCT OF EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 20-121. - Dress standards. 
Employees who are required by departmental regulations to wear a uniform will at all times, when on duty wear said uniform as specified by departmental regulations. The wearing of authorized uniforms for other than official duty, travel to or from such duty, or other specific wearing of the uniform is prohibited except where authorized by departmental regulations. All employees are expected to adhere to the principles of good taste and propriety in the selection of their clothing which will be worn for performing duties for the city. A guide for such consideration will be the acceptable standards of dress expected by the majority of those citizens served by the representative departments. Consideration will also be made concerning the type of service provided, including safety measures for bodily protection of the employee. The following clothing is not appropriate attire: shorts, halters, tank tops, jeans with holes, low neckline front or back, flip flops and slippers or clothing that has words, pictures, scenes, etc., that would be disruptive to the work environment. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-122. - Outside employment. 
No employee may engage in paid outside employment if such outside employment interferes with efficient performance of his duties and/or presents a conflict of interest. When outside employment creates a conflict of interest situation between the employee and the city, resignation from one of the positions held will be expected. Failure to comply with this regulation will constitute grounds for dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-123. - Pecuniary interest. 
Employees of the city shall not have financial interest in the profits of any contract, service or other work performed by the city; nor shall they personally profit directly or indirectly from any contract purchase sale or service between the city and any person or company. Any employee subject to these rules and regulations who violates the provisions of this section shall be guilty of misconduct in service and shall be subject to dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-124. - Political activity. 
(a)  No employee of the city shall be appointed, promoted, demoted, favored or discriminated against with respect to employment in the personnel system because of his political opinions or affiliations. 
(b)  No person shall use or promise to use any official authority or influence to secure an appointment or advantage in appointment to a position in the personnel system or an increase in pay or other advantage in employment. 
(c)  No employee in the personnel system shall solicit, take part in soliciting, pay or promise to pay any assessment for political purposes, subscription, contribution or service. 
(d)  No employee in the personnel system shall hold an elective office in the city government. Any employee seeking elective office shall take a leave of absence without pay from date of announcement through the duration of the campaign. If elected, the employee shall be separated form city service. 
An employee seeking elective office in the county, state or federal government shall be required to take a leave of absence without pay from the date of announcement through the duration of the campaign. 
(e)  Use of official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with an election or nomination for office, or affecting the result thereof shall constitute grounds for dismissal. 
(f)  Directly or indirectly coercing, attempting to coerce, commanding or advising any other officer or employee to pay, lend or contribute any part of his salary or compensation or anything else of value to any party, committee, organization, agency or person for political purposes is prohibited and shall result in dismissal. 
(g)  No employee in the city service will actively participate in local political party management or in local political campaigns or campaigning while on duty. This shall not be construed to restrict the rights of an employee covered by this chapter to vote in any election when qualified. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-125. - Gifts and gratuities. 
An employee shall not accept gifts, gratuities or loans from organizations, business concerns or individuals with whom he has official business. These limitations do not prohibit the acceptance of articles of negligible value which are distributed generally, nor do they prohibit employees from accepting social courtesies which promote good public relations, nor do they prohibit employees from obtaining loans from regular lending institutions. It is particularly important that inspectors, contracting officers and enforcement officers guard against relationships which might be construed as evidence of favoritism, coercion, unfair advantage or collusion. Violations of this policy will result in disciplinary action. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-126. - Use of safety belts by city employees. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "passenger vehicle" means every motor vehicle used by city employees during the course of their employment with the city, including trucks, but shall not mean vehicles which are not equipped with seat belts by the manufacturer of such vehicle. 
(b)  Each occupant of a passenger vehicle shall, while such passenger vehicle is being operated in the course of the business of the city and on a public road, street or highway of this state, be restrained by a safety belt approved under Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 208. 
(c)  The requirements of subsection (b) above shall not apply under the circumstances set forth in O.C.G.A. § 40-8-76.1(c)(1) through (9). 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-127—20-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - EMPLOYMENT OF RELATIVES 

Sec. 20-131. - Nepotism. 
(a)  In recognizing that there are situations where romantic, familial or other personal relationships between employees can adversely impact the conduct of the city's activities, the city has a policy perspective on such relationships. 
Basically, the city recognizes the right of individuals to privacy in their personal relationships and the city will only involve itself where such relationships have the potential to adversely impact the city's activities. 
It is not possible to outline all the scenarios which would cause concern to the city, but some of the more obvious include: 
-  Where one employee has access to sensitive, confidential information or to information not generally available to all employees. 
-  Where one employee is a manager or supervisor of the other involved employee. 
The city will treat any situations of this nature on a case-by-case basis. However, employees should be aware in advance that a likely outcome of such relationships is that one (1) of the employees involved may have to terminate employment to avoid potential adverse impact on the city's activities. 
(b)  Relatives of elected officials of the city and relatives of the city manager shall not be eligible for employment with the city. For purposes of this section, relatives shall mean spouse, children, parents, grandparents, grandchildren, brothers, sisters, brothers-in-law, sisters-in-law, nieces, nephews and the immediate family of a spouse. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-132—20-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - RECORDS AND REPORTING 

Sec. 20-141. - Personnel transactions. 
Department heads must comply with procedures administered by the city manager. All appointments, separations and other personnel transactions shall be made on forms designated by the personnel director. A separate file folder shall be prepared and maintained for each employee in a central file location and shall contain the original or [a] copy of all pertinent documents. This central file location shall be the official personnel file of the city, and records or documents kept in other locations or departments which are not copies of originals maintained in the central file, or originals at other locations or departments for which there are not copies in the central file shall not be considered as official personnel documents. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-142. - Types of records maintained. 
The city personnel director shall be charged with the responsibility of maintaining a complete personnel record file on each employee of the city. This personnel file will contain the employees application for employment, a chronological record of the employee's work history within the city service, a record of any commendations or disciplinary action taken against the employee, a record of all in-service training completed by the employee, a copy of all performance evaluations prepared on the employee and any other information received in connection with the employee's city employment. All information in the employee's personnel file shall be kept confidential except for verification of employment, salary and span of service. However, any employee or any person designated in writing by the employee will be entitled to review the employee's complete personnel file during the normal operating hours of the city personnel department. Personnel files may not be removed from the city personnel department and must be reviewed in the presence of the city manager or an employee of the personnel department. This provision will not prohibit the employee's supervisor, department head, the city manager, the mayor or any member of the personnel department from having access to those records in connection with the normal discharge of duties, nor shall it prohibit the city personnel committee from having access to the personnel file of any employee under review by said group. Any file removed from the personnel department for administrative action must remain under the custody of the personnel director or his designated representative or the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-143. - Public inspection. 
Any requests for public inspection of an employee's personnel records shall be made in writing, pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act. Only those portions of an employee's personnel file required by state law to be made available for public inspection shall be reviewed. As provided hereinabove, all personnel records shall be reviewed only in the presence of the city manager or an employee of the personnel department, and only during normal operating hours of the city personnel department. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-144. - Employee performance appraisal. 
The personnel director shall be charged with the maintenance of an effective performance appraisal system for all employees of the city. The performance appraisal program is designed to require each supervisor to effectively and objectively evaluate the performance of each employee on a regular basis and to advise the employee of his progress and strengths and weaknesses in carrying out the assigned duties and responsibilities. An employee will be evaluated in accordance with the provisions of the compensation plan, and it shall be the responsibility of the personnel department to maintain a roster of employees who are due performance appraisal during probationary periods and to establish the dates that performance based increase reviews are to be conducted. The personnel department will further advise the departments that appraisals are due and follow up to ensure that each employee is appraised of his performance as scheduled. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-145. - Attendance reports. 
Each department head shall prepare and submit regular attendance reports on the form and schedule designated by the personnel director. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-146—20-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - CLEARANCE PROCEDURE FOR TERMINATING EMPLOYEE 

Sec. 20-151. - Exit interview. 
An exit interview shall be conducted by the personnel director or his designated representative after receiving notification of the termination of an employee. The exit interview should include the following: 
(1)  Disbursement of employee's last paycheck, showing any and all deductions that may be required; 
(2)  Discussion of the employee's insurance program, his choice to drop or convert his insurance plan, and cost of same to him; and 
(3)  Discussing the reasons for the employee's termination as well as the employee's views concerning employment with the city. This information will be most beneficial to the personnel director in making evaluations of the city's personnel program. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-152. - Turn-in of property and equipment. 
At the time of separation and prior to final payment of a terminating employee, all records, assets and other items of city property in the employee's custody shall be transferred to the department head or his designated representative and notification to this effect shall be forwarded to the city personnel department for inclusion in the employee's personnel file. Any funds due, because of the shortage in accounting for city property shall be withheld from the employee's final compensation or collected through other appropriate action. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-153—20-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - COMPLAINTS BY PRIVATE CITIZENS 

Sec. 20-171. - Complaint procedure. 
Any private citizen who has a complaint to lodge against any employee of the city should make the complaint in writing to the head of the department in which the person is employed within ten (10) calendar days of the date of the incident which resulted in the complaint. The department head will be charged with the responsibility of investigating the complaint, taking any action that he might deem appropriate in connection with the complaint, and notifying in writing the citizen lodging the complaint of his findings and any action that has been taken. If the private citizen is not satisfied with the action taken by the department head regarding the complaint against an employee, he may request that the city personnel committee review the complaint and the action taken by the department head. Such request must be made in writing and filed with the city manager within ten (10) calendar days of the date of receipt of the notification of the action taken by the department head. The city personnel committee will review complaints appropriately filed with the committee by private citizens, take any action the committee deems appropriate and notify the citizen in writing within thirty (30) calendar days of receipt of the complaint of the disposition of the complaint. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-172—20-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVIII. - SEXUAL HARASSMENT 

Sec. 20-181. - Application. 
This article shall apply to all city employees. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-182. - Introduction. 
The purpose of this directive is to establish city policy concerning allegations of sexual harassment; to prohibit sexual harassment; to establish proper reporting procedures for reporting instances of sexual harassment and to define instances, happenings and occurrences of sexual harassment. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-183. - Policy. 
The city condemns and will not condone sexual harassment. If an employee feels that unwelcome sexual advances, language or other forms of sexual harassment are interfering with the employee's productivity or comfort at the workplace or feels that any term or condition of employment depends on sexual favors, the employee is encouraged to immediately report the incident to the employee's immediate supervisor. It should be understood that a claim of sexual harassment may bypass the normal grievance procedure and that the claim can be expressed privately to the employee's department head. If the claimant feels that reporting to the employee's immediate supervisor or department head may adversely affect the employee's employment, the claim may be expressed to the city clerk or city manager. Any complaints of sexual harassment will be handled in an expeditious and fair manner and any violation of this policy may result in discipline up to and including termination. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-184. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases as used in this article, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context, shall have the following meanings: 
Employee. All city personnel. 
Sexual harassment. Unwelcome sexual advances, requests for sexual favors and other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature constitute sexual harassment when: (1) submission to such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a term or condition of an individual's employment; (2) submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis for employment decisions affecting such individual; or (3) such conduct has a purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering with an individual's work performance, or creating an intimidating, hostile, or offensive working environment. Sexual harassment is not gender specific, and does not require that the victim suffer physical or psychological injury or economic loss. Examples of sexual harassment include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Sexual comments of a provocative or suggestive nature, or about a person's body or body parts; 
(2)  Sexual oriented jokes or innuendos which degrade men or women; 
(3)  Suggestive or demeaning looks or leering; 
(4)  Creating an intimidating, hostile or offensive working environment; 
(5)  Touching, pinching or patting; 
(6)  Insulting or suggestive sounds; 
(7)  Cartoons, pinups, calendars, pictures, etc. of naked men or women or of a sexual nature; 
(8)  Repeated flirtations or sexual comments; 
(9)  Turning work discussions into sexual topics; 
(10)  Repeated insults against men or women; 
(11)  Making acceptance of unwelcomed sexual conduct or advances or requests for sexual favors of any nature a condition of employment, employment decisions or continued employment; and 
(12)  Conduct of a sexual nature that has the purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering with an individual's work performance. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-185. - Reporting procedure. 
(a)  An employee who believes he or she has been sexually harassed shall contact the immediate supervisor. An employee may also contact the city clerk or city manager. A report documenting the complaint will be prepared and forwarded to the city manager. 
(b)  In order not to discourage victims from reporting incidents, an offended employee is not required to first complain to his or her immediate supervisor, who may be the alleged harasser. 
(c)  Allegations of unwelcomed sexual harassment shall be reported immediately by the offended employee. A victim's voluntary submission to sexually harassing behavior has no bearing on a determination of welcomeness. 
(d)  Complaints and the identities of the involved personnel shall be kept as confidential as possible recognizing that the complexity and breadth of a thorough investigation normally preclude any guarantee of absolute confidentiality. 
(e)  No employee complaining of harassment or participating in any investigation of harassment will be retaliated against in any way. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-186. - Department heads and supervisory personnel. 
(a)  Department heads and supervisory personnel shall: 
(1)  Be responsible for reporting instances of sexual harassment on appropriate City forms; 
(2)  Take immediate action to limit the affected employees from any further work contact during an investigation while making certain that no corrective step punishes or adversely affects the complainant or alleged harasser; 
(3)  Deal immediately with problematic conduct of which they are aware even in the absence of a complaint; and 
(4)  Be responsible for initiating immediate disciplinary action if the situation warrants. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-187. - Investigation. 
(a)  Any complaint of sexual harassment shall result in a prompt and thorough investigation of the complaint. 
(b)  The procedures and methodology used to build a reliable and factual record with as many specifics as possible shall be thoroughly documented. Investigators should avoid legal or conclusory terminology. This is not a criminal investigation and phrases such as probable cause should not be used. 
(c)  The complainant shall be interviewed and should be encouraged to put the complaint in writing. The sequence of events, the time and location of incidents, language used in conversations, and physical actions should be described and transcribed as exactly as possible. The investigator should encourage the complainant to be forthright in describing lewd, embarrassing, or horrific language and incidents, and also ask the complainant what he or she did in response without insinuating that the victim is to blame in any way. Witnesses or physical evidence should also be identified. 
(d)  Witnesses shall be interviewed. 
(e)  The alleged harasser shall be interviewed and given an opportunity to respond to the charges, rebut any accusations and to present his or her version of events. The rights of the accused must be respected. 
(f)  If an investigation uncovers harassment from other individuals or situations independent of the complaint, separate but integrated investigations and remedial action should be initiated. 
(g)  Both the complainant and the alleged harasser will be notified of the outcome of the investigation. 
(h)  A detailed report of the investigation shall be given to the department head as soon as it is completed in order that prompt and appropriate remedial actions may be taken to correct the situation. 
(i)  In the event that an investigation is inconclusive, the alleged harasser will be warned that sexual harassment will not be tolerated and is a serious violation of city policy. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Sec. 20-188. - Training. 
(a)  All city personnel shall receive a copy of this sexual harassment policy. Each employee shall acknowledge, in writing, receipt and understanding of the policy. 
(b)  All city department heads and supervisors shall receive training on recognizing and remediating sexual harassment. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, 7-6-10) 
Secs. 20-189—20-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIX. - SUBSTANCE ABUSE 

Sec. 20-191. - Purpose 
The city is committed to providing a safe work environment and to fostering the well-being and health of its employees.
